title: diamond-wedding-couple-vow-celebrate-style-lockdown
story: Liz and Billy Mitchell toasted  years of married le at their home in Dunbar last Thursday, alongside son Colin and daughter-in-law Charmaine.They were surrounded by dozens of cards, including one from Her Majesty The Queen.Lizrsquos mum and dad, Cathy and John Harvey, also celebrated their diamond wedding anniversary with a card from HM The Queen in .Speaking on Friday, Liz said: ldquoWe were going to have a do in West Barns Bowling Club.ldquoWe have made an awful lot of nice new friends down here.ldquoIt has been like a second le to us coming down here and everything has been great and we have thoroughly enjoyed it.ldquoWe were just in the house and could not do anything but we got as many cards, presents and dferent things that have been handed in.ldquoIt was really lovely yesterday. It was all we could do but the whole crowd of us have said once this terrible time is over we are going to have a joint party in the bowling club and we will get together again.Billy and Liz on their wedding dayCoronavirus restrictions have meant the couple have missed out on a number of milestones, with Liz, originally from Musselburgh, turning  towards the end of last year and Billy reaching the same age two months earlier.Colin and Charmaine were also due to mark their pearl wedding anniversary last year.A joint holiday in Skye was planned to celebrate the double wedding anniversary.Liz and Billy, who live on the townrsquos John Muir Crescent, met when they both worked for haulage firm Pollock, which was based at Newbigging in Musselburgh.Billy was a driver with the company for a number of years, while Liz worked in the office, before going to work with the local authority as the manager of the home help service in the social work service for more than  years.They were married at Musselburgh Congregational Church on March , , and headed off on their honeymoon to the north of England, with a stopover at the Royal Mackintosh Hotel in Dunbar.It would continue Lizrsquos love of the town, which she moved to along with Billy  years ago.She said: ldquoI used to love Dunbar. When I was a kid, my mum and dad used to bring me down to the beach.ldquoAt the weekend, we had picnics and would always come to Dunbar.ldquoI never thought I would be living here!The couple also have one grandson, -year-old Ruaridh, and Liz stressed there was no real secret to a happy marriage, other than good communication.She said: ldquoYou just have to talk to each other. All these people that say they have never had a cross word, I donrsquot believe that for a minute! When you do have anything, you have got to sit down and talk about it donrsquot let it linger.ldquoWe have got the same interests, which is good.ldquoYou have your ups and downs but that is le.ldquoI donrsquot think there is any secret ndash you have got to work at it.

title: new-netflix-feature-stop-sharing-passwords-friends-family
story: Some users reported being met with a screen reading: ldquoIf you donrsquot live with the owner of this account, you need your own account to keep watching.Viewers are reportedly given the option to very their identity through a code sent to the accountrsquos owner or can choose to complete the process later.In a statement, Netflix said: ldquoThis test is designed to help ensure that people using Netflix accounts are authorised to do so.The move could lead to a crackdown on the sharing of passwords.However, Netflix has previously said it was happy for account owners to share their passwords.Speaking in , CEO Reed Hastings said the company had ldquono plans on a crackdown.He said: ldquoPassword sharing is something you have to learn to live with, because therersquos so much legitimate password sharing, like you sharing with your spouse, with your kids. So therersquos no bright line, and wersquore doing fine as is.According to the Netflix terms of service, account details should ldquonot be shared with iniduals beyond your household.In the UK, a monthly subscription ranges in cost from pound. to pound., depending on the package.Last month, the streaming giant increased its standard package ndash which allows two screens to access an account, as well as HD ndash by pound per month, from pound. to pound..The premium package ndash providing four-screen access per account and Ultra HD ndash was bumped up by pound, from pound. to pound., while the one-screen non-HD basic plan will remain at pound. per month.Netflix said the price hikes are essential to reflect the ldquosignicant investments it has made in new TV shows and films.ldquoThis year wersquore spending over one billion dollars in the UK on new, locally made films, series and documentaries, helping to create thousands of jobs and showcasing British storytelling at its best ndash with everything from The Crown to Sex Education and Top Boy, plus many, many more, a Netflix spokesperson said.They added: ldquoOur price change reflects the signicant investments wersquove made in new TV shows and films, as well as improvements to our product.In January the company, boosted by months of lockdown, revealed it had more than  million subscribers, making it the worldrsquos leading streaming service.

title: human-remains-found-kent-identified-sarah-everard
story: On Wednesday night, Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick said unidentied human remains had been found in an area of woodland in Ashford, in Kent, by detectives investigating Ms Everardrsquos disappearance.Speaking today to reporters outside Scotland Yard, Assistant Commissioner Nick Ephgrave said the body found in woodland in Kent was that of Sarah Everard.He said: ldquoAs you know, on Wednesday evening detectives investigating the disappearance of Sarah Everard discovered a body secreted in woodland in Kent.ldquoThe body has now been recovered and formal identication procedure has now been undertaken.ldquoI can now confirm that it is the body of Sarah Everard.Nick Ephgrave said that Sarah Everardrsquos family had been told this ldquomost distressing news.The politan Police officer accused of her murder remains in custody, he added.On Thursday, The family of Sarah Everard have paid tribute to her as a ldquoshining example to us all, describing her as a daughter and sister who ldquobrought so much joy to our lives.Her family said: ldquoOur beautul daughter Sarah was taken from us and we are appealing for any information that will help to solve this terrible crime.ldquoSarah was bright and beautul ndash a wonderful daughter and sister. She was kind and thoughtful, caring and dependable. She always put others first and had the most amazing sense of humour.ldquoShe was strong and principled and a shining example to us all. We are very proud of her and she brought so much joy to our lives.ldquoWe would like to thank our friends and family for all their support during this awful time and we would especially like to thank Sarahrsquos friends who are working tirelessly to help.

title: iain-gray-msp-praises-east-lothian-final-holyrood-speech
story: He was speaking at Holyrood during the stage three debate on the Redress for Survivors Bill.Mr Gray, who is retiring as an MSP in May, expressed his support for the bill, adding that he was title: kinrara-low-level-stroll-among-pines-suitable-abilities
story: Grade: Easy low-level walkDistance:  miles kmTime: - hoursSITUATED between Kingussie and Aviemore, Kinrara Estate has had a chequered history in terms of public access. However, a number of years ago a lsquopath orderrsquo was taken out by the Cairngorms National Park to enable an extension of the Speyside Way to cross part of the -acre estate, an extension opposed by the estate owners on the basis that it would interfere with nature conservation.This was the first time the Land ReformAct  had been used to solve an access dispute and after ministers had approved the path order it was eventually built, providing an undulating route between Aviemore and Kincraig.Part of that section of the Speyside Way is included in this route, a very pleasant jaunt that takes you through the wooded heart of Kinrara before ing to the starting point via the new footpath.Starting point for the walk is the small car park adjacent to the entrance to the Dalraddy Holiday Park. We wandered through the underpass below the railway line and turned left to access the tarmac road that wersquod follow for the next km.Despite the tarmac underfoot this is a glorious walk through mixed woodland with distant views across the River Spey to the high tops of the Cairngorms.On our visit it was a dark and gloomy afternoon but it was good to see buzzards spiralling above us and blue tits and even some coal tits in amongst the very impressive old pines.On our left, wooded slopes rose to the summit called Tor Alvie where a huge obelisk points to the sky ndash the Duke of Gordon monument, built to commemorate the last Duke of Gordon who died in . Close by is another monument, the Waterloo Cairn, erected by the Marquis of Huntly in  to remember the soldiers of the Gordon Highlanders who died at the Battle of Waterloo in .The tarmac road led us past Kinrara House, formerly the summer home of the Duchess of Gordon, whom Wikipedia describes as a lsquoScottish Tory political hostess.rsquoAlong with her husband, the th Duke of Gordon and her son George, Jane, Duchess of Gordon was a founder of the Gordon Highlanders, an infantry regiment that existed until .Itrsquos said she was a patron of Robert Burns. Itrsquos also claimed that she encouraged young men to join up by offering them the Kingrsquos shilling, held between her lips.The recruits got their recruiting payment and a kiss into the bargain!We wandered on past some keepersrsquo cottages with the hillside on our left now covered in juniper bushes.Further on we passed a track running off to our left before we dropped down towards some reedy, shallow lochans. There is a lovely view here back over the water to the sharp rise of Tor Alvie.Soon we were back in pine woods before reaching a cottage beyond which lay ourroute to Dalraddy, the troublesome section of the Speyside Way.This long distance trail runs from Spey Bay on the Moray Firth to Newtonmore and this sections more or less parallels the London to Inverness railway.Itrsquos an undulating trail, with one or two steep sections and a short section on wooden boards where it crosses marshy ground. Itrsquos straightforward in terms of navigation though ndash just stick to the path and you wonrsquot go wrong.We soon reached the road we followed earlier and simply crossed over and followed our outward route back to Dalraddy car park, the end of a short but very satisfying route that made the most of a glowering January afternoon.Cameron McNeishROUTE PLANNERMap: OS :, Landranger sheet Harveys Map of the Speyside WayStart Finish: Car park adjacent to the entrance to Dalraddy Holiday Park Distance:  miles kmTime: - hoursInformation: Aviemore TIC,  .Route: Go through underpass below the railway. Almost immediately TL through a gate. Follow the path to a minor road. Follow road for km, past Kinrara House and some keepersrsquo cottages, past lochans and over a stream. When you pass a cottage on your L watch out for Speyside Way signs pointing L. Follow the undulating path, paralleling the railway all the way back to the tarmac road. Cross road and follow path back to the the railway underpass. Go back through the underpass to the car park.Due to current restrictions, we are running our favourite previously published walks. Please follow the Scottish Governmentrsquos coronavirus restrictions, see www.gov.scot  coronavirus-covid-

title: scots-word-week-bield
story: MOTHERrsquoS Day tomorrow put me in mind of this weekrsquos word. Dictionaries of the Scots Languagedefines bield iously as ldquoprotection, shelter, ldquoa place affording shelter, and ldquoa protector. Early examples date back to the  century, as in James Kellyrsquos Collection of Scottish Proverbs : ldquoEvery Man bows to the Bush he gets beel of. Burnsrsquo poem Winter of Leis also cited: ldquoMy trunk of eild [age in general], but buss or bield, Sinks in timersquos wintry rage.The term survives into the modern period, and not only in poetry. Lavinia Derwent, in her  autobiography A Border Bairn, gives us the following description: ldquoPheasants and partridges were expert at camouflage, making simple bields on the ground amongst heather and bracken, carefully covering them with dead leaves or grass before flying off to forage for food. DSL also records the following verbal pitch-side instruction from Selkirk in : ldquoUse that [rugby] pitch ndash itrsquos better bieldit.Bield is still in use in the st century. A short story, Timrsquos Tales: Jamie and the elder tree, by Tim Porteous, published in the East Lothian Courier of December , uses it thus: ldquoHe set aff hame, but stopped fir a moment tae turn roond an look at the elder tree. Its bare branches hud been sculpted by the wind, and wi the backgroond orsquo snaw, it looked like a figure bent ower an image orsquo an auld wummin makin a bield fir her bairn.Scots Word of the Week is written by Pauline Cairns Speitel, Dictionaries of the Scots Language https:dsl.ac.uk

title: cail-bruich-home---ron-mackennas-verdict-185-michelin-star-takeaway
story: LETrsquoS fast forward past the unpacking, the instruction-poring over, the loud groan when we realise the main course is as-yet-uncooked duck, the tweaking and plating and on, again, into the first course.A sourdough loaf just warmed in the oven, marmite butter with an ooh-thatrsquos-unusual aftertaste and already a little bit of theatre.Lids are slowly being unscrewed from two anodised and shoe polish-shaped tinshelliptwist, twist, twisthelliprevealing a jewel-like portrait of glistening Exmoor caviar, tiny squirts of posh mayo, a translucent membrane made, possibly, impossibly even, from grapefruit then sweet juicy crab bursting with flavour underneath.Boom, the tins are emptied in a succession of breezy teaspoonfuls. And we move on.More art, another feast for the eyes, a wafer of translucent paper under a magnicent duck parfait, layered, coloured in duns and dapples, crimson fillets of rhubarb brazenly razor cut across the grain, micro blobs of macro flavours popping, an actual just-made-in-Glasgow today brioche too.Itrsquos all so luxurious, so satisfying. RON:Pasta Evangelists, London. Ron Mackennas home delivery reviewAwaiting are tiny handmade pastato be draped in a truffle and asparagus sauce that slowly fills the bowl and has us nodding at how brilliantly deep, yet almost mayonnaisely tangy the whole thing is, though was it meant to be a soup And now wersquore unwrapping parchment paper parcels pulled from the oven, their crisped edges springing back to reveal cod fillets, crusted with hazelnut and lemonhellipwhoahelliphang on. You donrsquot really think it happened like this Springing from box to table in a magical Mary Michelin-star Poppins moment, us all chim-chim-charrooing along. Like hell it does.Itrsquos check-how-long this-takes, set the phone timer-to-that. Hey, wersquore running out of pans and dishes. Wait, make-it-look-like-itrsquos-supposed-to on the plate. Now sit down and eat. Get up and check the next course.Herersquos what they donrsquot tell you in this Michelin-star home movie:you really, really want to enjoy this glorious food you actually, genuinely, need to hire someone to put it all together while you sit and soak up the ambience.Anyway, letrsquos air brush over the fafforama and cut to the cod. Yes, we follow the instructions to the very second. No, it is definitely not ready when it is supposed to be. Yes, it gets rewrapped and blasted in the oven again.And at the re-unveiling of the parchment  Hey, lovely, a tart Verjus sauce to sprinkle round those pearl white flakes, that deep herby crust pile-driving in the sensations, and a subtle salty edge from the kale.Itrsquos an important moment in this meal: because from here on in things go very, very pound home-delivery pear-shaped wrong.The fth course then. Aka La Debacle. Honestly  As soon as the duck was pulled from its wrapping, perfectly butchered as it was, I knew we were in for a rough ride.Pop into a lightly oiled pan at medium heat, apply a little pressure and wait for skin to crisp, the instructions cheerily read.Yeah, right. Maybe in a professional kitchen.A minute on the other side, it continues. Spoon over honey, oven for two minutes, rest for fourthen itrsquos ready.Really  Not a chance. RON:Private Chef Hobbins. Home delivery review by Ron MackennaItrsquos not crisp. Itrsquos so uncooked it quacks when I go near it, and back in it goes again. We actually enjoy the rest of the dish, the chocolate smooth confit duck rolls, punchy wild leek and garlic, spiced jus separately from the breast. Which remains disappointing throughout.Therersquos a supplementary course of a Tamworth cheese tartwhich looks pretty, tastes tangy but the pastry is just damp and limp. At least fun-filled chunks of glittery honeycomb, biscuitty sprinkles, bitter lemon droplets turn an effervescent yoghurt dessert into a success.As for Michelin magic at home. They may well know what theyrsquore doing but do we Cail Bruich At Home Great Western RoadGlasgowMenu: Seven-course tasting menu comes with petit fours, sourdough, brioche, more jus, sprinkles, teasing and tweaking than you can sake a broomstick at, plus lovely cod, duckand of course the magic only a Michelin star brings.  Price: We took the extra Tamworth cheese tartpushing the price of this takeaway for two to, gulp, pound. Donrsquot snort therersquos a stampede to get a taste of Glasgowrsquos first Michelin starred restaurant for decades.  Atmosphere: Listen, they do a huge amount of preparation and their skills are obvious, as is Michelin starred-chef Lorna McNeersquos brilliance, but in the home kitchen  Itrsquos a sht. Still a lot of work to get to the table.  Service: There were still many pound boxes stacked to be collected when I picked mine up from cheery staff. The instructions are clear and professional but the timings seemed way out for a home oven.  Food: Michelin food at home is what yoursquore paying for and for the most part itrsquos bright, brilliant and very enjoyable. Duck breast from scratch is a bad idea as itrsquos so hard to get right, the tart was floppy, but otherwise great food.   ronmackenna@me

title: crock-gold-rounds-shane-macgowan
story: Crock Of Gold: A Few Rounds With Shane MacGowan.Boxing or drinking Both metaphors work when talking about the feature- documentary film billed as "an exploration of the legendary frontman of Anglo-Irish Celtic punk band The Pogues". Released late last year into limited cinemas and on digital s, Crock Of Gold will now enjoy an airing on BBC Four.Tell me more.Directed by Julien Temple ndash known for his short films on the Sex Pistols and left-field projects such as the mockumentary The Great Rock n Roll Swindle ndash Crock Of Gold delves into the explosive le and career of the Irish punk poet.Shane MacGowan performs on stage in . Picture: Andrew CatlinThrough interviews, rarely seen archive footage and a memorable soundtrack, it charts MacGowans early childhood growing up on the family farm in Tipperary then, later, embracing the punk scene in London, forming The Pogues and finding international fame in the s and early s.Anything  The film paints an intimate portrait of MacGowan, laying bare his passions, humour and deep knowledge of music, history and spirituality, as well as addressing his demons and darkest days. It also shatters a few enduring myths along the way.:Line of Duty:  reasons why we love the hit police dramaWhen can I watch Crock Of Gold: A Few Rounds With Shane MacGowan is on BBC Four, Tuesday, pm.

title: herald-sunday-letters-harry-meghan-faced-grand-inquisitor-like-paxman-marr-neil
story: I was reminded of that watching Oprah Winfrey interviewing Mr and Mrs Harry Windsor, with the latters actress skills in full display ndash the exaggerated looks of shock and stage-managed gasps of indignation and the repetition of key sentences for full effect.One craved seeing them interviewed by a grand inquisitor like Jeremy Paxman, Andrew Marr or Andrew Neil. They would have leapt on rehearsed statements such as "I wanted to die", "the English tabloids were all racist" and "racism stopped Archie becoming a Prince". Those three would not be fazed by Meghans default position that criticising her marks you out as racist, sexist or misogynistic.ITN, which badly misjudged the public mood, had assured us there would be a  million US TV audience, even more than the US Super bowl, Mary Nightingale emphasised.The audience was m. In the UK it came in at less than Gavin And Stacey.Netflix will view those figures with trepidation.John V Lloyd, Inverkeithing.STURGEON WAS CALM AND CLEARIAIN Macwhirter must have listened to a dferent oral evidence session from Nicola Sturgeon than the one to which I did last Wednesday. His articlefocuses heavily on a very short period of the session where the Conservative Murdo Fraser suggested Ms Sturgeon should apologise for her previous support of Mr Salmond. Ms Sturgeon dealt with that rather questionable issue with self-restraint.Prior to and after this matter Ms Sturgeon calmly and clearly answered questions put to her for seven hours. Her patience must have been sorely tried when ious members of the committee repeatedly asked the same questions of the First Minister. All were dealt with politely and efficiently.Eileen Michael, Ralston.WHAT ABOUT THE WESTMINSTER MESS YET another article from Iain Macwhirter on the Alex Salmond Nicola Sturgeon issue. May I suggest to Mr Macwhirter that other subjects he might have devoted his column to include the pound. million which was spent on Downing Street refurbishments, the pound,-plus legal expenses paid to Sir Philip Rutnam regarding claims of bullying by Priti Patelor the fact that the SNP welcomed , new members to its ranks within two days of Ms Sturgeon giving evidence to the Holyrood committee.Ruth Marr, Stirling.ALL ABOUT THE DEMOCRATIC DEFICITREADERS must be well aware by now that Dr Gerald Edwards detests the independence movement, directing his fire mainly at the SNP which,any of his invective is to be taken seriously, would have to be aiming to create an independent state in which it would govern unopposed.He explains todaythat for independence to be credible Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP must demonstrate higher standards than other parties and be "beyond reproach". What a load of utter tripe. The credible case for independence has nothing to do with Nicola Sturgeon or the SNP and everything to do with the democratic deficit which denies the Scottish nation political self-determination.Willie Maclean, Milngavie.WE NEED SO MUCH BETTERNO, Gavin Ferguson , Nicola Sturgeon is not being ripped down over a ldquoprocedural anomaly ndashyou can call misleading parliament and the people of Scotland an ldquoanomaly. She is being ripped down as this is the culmination of a disgraceful term in power where she has trashed virtually every aspect of Scottish le. Only the judiciary and civil service were left and she has now trashed them also.The pandemic and the Salmond Sturgeon affair have, conveniently for this regime, placed on the back-burner, her woeful record on education: why not publish the OECD report now as opposed to June on Police Scotland, a poundm black hole on GP surgeries close on the highest drug deaths in Europe on child hunger on homelessness, on vanity projects such as Prestwick and BiFab costing taxpayers more than pound million, on ferries unable to be completed and at triple cost on a new hospital lying empty on the named person scheme and on and on and on. All of these, as indeed confirmed my Ms Sturgeon in September , are of lesser importance than independence.This is a regime where every aspect of our lives has been sacriced on the altar of separation because destruction of the UK is the priority. We need, we demand so much better than this. That Scotland has been so damaged is a disgrace and I earnestly hope ldquothe people of Scotland will ensure the cancer of nationalism is damaged beyond repair in May. Nationalists clearly are content with a sub-standard government, the rest of us are not.Douglas Cowe, Newmachar.NO BREXIT CATASTROPHE YETAFTER all the hyperbole from the SNP of clf edge, catastrophe and disasterswe left the EU, it is reassuring to know and see that the wider UK Government has secured enough vaccines for all of us in the UK and we now see clear signs the vaccine is gaining the upper hand against the virus since leaving the EU, also that the US-imposed % tarf imposed on Scotch whisky while being part of the EU, which cost our industry pound million in business, has been lted as a consequence of being outside the EU tarf wars.It seems we are better off outside the tent.Contrast this with the vitriol between which SNP First Minister told the most least lies and the fancul claims by SNP propspective candidate Toni Giugliano that we can double our pensions with SNP, it is clear that while the party and Nicola Sturgeon can certainly talk, the UK takes action.As an ex-EU Remainer" I am still waiting for the prophesied "clf edge catastrophe", but so far, so good, so lets get on with it.Allan Thompson, Bearsden.CHANCE TO REVAMP EDUCATIONWITH every crisis comes an opportunity.The pandemic has disrupted the educational progress of our primary and secondary pupils, the proper remedy for which is for them all to repeat the whole year to ensure that they proceed to the next stage properly prepared and equipped to handle the demands of the careers they hope and wish to pursue. Robert Frazerwas right to point out that there would be a blockage in the school systemmy proposalwere not refined to counteract that dficulty.What I would be proposing and had not clearly explained in my initial submission is that primary education would become an eight-year cycle, each new intake being inducted into a pre-primary year before entering upon primary one.That would mean primary pupils going to secondary one year later than they do now and, of course, leaving secondary one year on from the age they do now Primary schools would need extra staff, extra finance and more accommodation in the form of huts to service this change .What would the kids do in the pre-primary stage  Well, the groundwork for their future educational progress would be laid.They would be drilled properly in their times tables and they would be shown the importance of proper spelling. However, that year would also give them taster courses in the wonders of the night sky, the identication of trees from their leaves and birds from their appearance and song.There would be a gentle introduction to the cultural stories which infuse our literature from Greek, Roman ,Norse and Christian mythologies.They could also be exposed to the work of the great composers and artists during that year before embarking upon the curriculum supposedly designated to prepare them for advancing onwards and upwards to secondary level and beyond.Let us hope our politicians do not lose this opportunity to revamp our educational system and to ensure that those whose progress has been impaired by the pandemic do not suffer as a consequence.Denis Bruce, Bishopbriggs.STAYCATION ARTICLE WAS MISLEADINGYOUR article on staycation prices which was headlined across the front page ldquoThe great Scottish summer staycation RIP OFFwas as misleading as it was irresponsible.The figures quoted are quite right ndash tourism contributes a signicant amount to the Scottish economy, yet only three holiday providers were cited. Of those, two were found to have signicantly increased prices for periods of high demand. While this is nothing new and both companies admitted to the policy, neither of those companies is Scottish, Hoseasons being based in Lowestoft and Havenin Hemel Hempstead. The one Scottish business quoted said it is not increasing prices.The headline across pages four and fiveincluded hotels in the alleged ldquopandemic profiteering, but no example was given. As the owner of a small hotel in Argyll, I am acutely aware that the leisure and tourism industry is on its knees, however, like the owners of Dalriada Luxury Lodges, and for the same reasons, we do not intend to increase our tarf this season.Articles such as this could do much damage to our industry.Christine Stevenson, Cairnbaan Hotel, Lochgilphead.LICENSE THE CATSI AGREE with Ron McKayand Anne Shackleton that dog licences should be reintroduced. I would also like to see cat owners having to have a licence for their furry friends. So many cats are let out on their own to defecate in other peoples gardens. Cats should be taken out on a lead and owners should pick up the mess.There are serious infections one can get from cat faeces and I personally do not appreciate having to pick other owners cat mess from my garden.Pearl Stuart, Thornliebank.

title: clydebank-blitz-80-years-heroism-horror
story: Busloads of people were already making their way to the area, looking for parents, relatives, lovers, fearful of what they might find. Among them was Mary A. Carson, the editor of the Womens Topic pages in this newspaper since , whose nom de plume was Jean Kelvin.ldquoWe have walked along those devastated streets, she subsequently wrote, ldquocrunching all the time over littered glass speedily being swept into the gutters. We have seen those shattered modest homes. If one looked for it, no doubt there was the lighter side ndash two children dancing unconcernedly on a novel stage, the cleared and windowless frontage of a shop and the incongruous, those odd personal items standing still intact before gaping walls.Carsons article appeared  years ago, on Monday, March , , in the aftermath of the Clydeside Blitz. Clydebank and parts of Glasgow had been bombed on the nights of the th, a Thursday, and th, Friday. It has been said of the first night, when the planes, some  of them, arrived in three waves between pm on the Thursday and . the following morning, that you could hear the explosions in Bridge of Allan, in Stirlingshire you could see the fiery glow in the night sky as far away as rural Aberdeenshire.ldquoWe have seen", Carson continued, "weary-eyed firemen, strained-looking wardens, tired soldiers about their business among the debris. We have seen a delicate, white-haired lady have to be firmly restrained from going to help them, and when warned of the havoc in her lovely home, refuse to be concerned.One sight in particular remained with her: huddles of people standing beside bedding laid out on the pavement. ldquoThose women and men everywhere with their pathetic little cases and bundles those patient evacuees at the rest centres, waiting to be shepherded to this place, or the next place, it did not matter where.Since the previous September, Scottish people had been reading of the catastrophic damage visited upon towns and cities in England by the Luftwaffe. London was first bombed on September , when  people were killed the capital was then bombed for  consecutive nights.What followed was "a winter of horror, death, demoralisation ndash and heroism". Coventry was devastated on November -  people died. Then came Birmingham, Bristol, Southampton, Sheffield, Liverpool, Manchester, Cardf, Portsmouth and Hull, as the Luftwaffe focused its attention on key provincial cities and industrial centres and, eventually, ports.Aberdeen had already been targeted, and was on its way to being ldquoScotlandrsquos front-line town. Thirty-four people were killed there on July . The enemy planes arrival over Aberdeen was for a time so regular that a remark would do the rounds: "Its just about time for Jerry".Glasgow had been attacked, too, in July and September. A young female shop assistant in the city said she had seen a German plane ldquolike a speck in the sky, dropping a bomb. ldquoIt seemed to be coming straight for us, and I got a terrible shock. It landed about  yards away, and before I heard the crash I saw a column of smoke and debris thrown high into the air from the house it struck.People who lived in Clydebank had been bracing themselves for an onslaught, aware that the presence of the John Brown  Co shipyard, as well as an armaments factory in the Singer Sewing Machine Works, and the Beardmore engine works, made it vulnerable.The Clydebank-born artist, Tom McKendrick, who has researched the Clydebank Blitz deeply, has noted that though many felt that the towns industrial profile marked it as prime target, some believed that the iron in the mountains surrounding Clydeside would interfere with the compasses of aircraft, thus making reliable target navigation impossible.By March , Clydebank, a town with a population of ,, had long grown accustomed to the piercing wail of alarms. There had been some   alarms in the preceding month alone. ldquoThe siren would go, perhaps because a single aircraft was flying overhead, one man recalled in a  BBC documentary on the Blitz, ldquoso in the event, when the sirens went on the thirteenth of March, a lot of people thought initially, itrsquos another  alarm.But it wasnt.ldquoAll the lights went out, and then we heard one or two crumps here and there, the first bombs starting to fall, remarked a second man. A third: ldquoThe next thing was an explosion hellip there was just a helter-skelter of debris. We knew this was no longer fun, we were a target.Helen Robertson, an air raid warden at the time, would recollect in : ldquoI remember incendiaries were falling just like flowers on a carpet, hundreds of them.Helenrsquos story is among many included in Untold Stories: Remembering Clydebank in Wartime, which was put together by the Clydebank Le Story Group. There are so many vivid, painful memories of loss and destruction in its pages. One more will suffice here, from Jean Golder, who was on ARP duty: ldquoI was on night sht and it was the most terrible experience of my le, the planes screaming, bombs exploding and the smell of burning ."When we were allowed to make our way home, tears were streaming down our faces as we looked towards what had been terraced houses on the hill. There was nothing left but huge piles of rubble of what we called the lsquoHoly Cityrsquo.The staggering impact of the bombs and incendiaries on Clydebank has been well documented. Second Avenue had the highest number of deaths ndash  ndash when a parachute mine ripped the face off  yards of terraced housing, McKendrick writes. Entire families were wiped out as tenement buildings collapsed, crushing the occupants who had sought shelter in lower floors and closes.On the Friday morning, says John MacLeod in his vivid book, River of Fire, thousands of ldquodazed, filthy, bloodied survivors made their way along Dumbarton Road into Glasgow.That night, the Germans ed:  aircraft this time. Few people were left in Clydebank by this time, but many townsfolk would assert that this second raid was a more vindictive raid than the first, says MacLeod.A news report in Saturdays Glasgow Herald said that the ldquolong and fierce attack had been carried out ldquowith a grim and revolting sadism by relays of raiders hellip What angered Clydeside was not the fact that they were being raided. It was an attention they had expected. But they felt the insensate fury of the attack had not the manner or methods of an attempt to dislocate industry rather did they take it as a deliberate adventure in terrorism.By the Saturday night, ldquothe near-fabulous total of over , people had left the town . Homeless Bankies were sent to accommodation in towns across the central belt. ldquoThe town was all but destroyed. From one geographically small community,  people were dead  seriously injured. Hundreds ndash perhaps thousands ndash more were superficially hurt and cut. Of some , dwellings ndash including tenement blocks as well as villas and semi-detached homes ndash only seven were left entirely undamaged. Four thousand homes were completely destroyed , would be uninhabitable for months.Blitz victims were laid to rest without much ceremony in mass burials. The  Register of Deaths for Old or West Kirkpatrick registration district bears the names of over  of those who died in Clydebank. The cause of death is stated as lsquoDue to war operations.rsquoldquoWe were now seeing for the first time among our own people what had happened where, Mary Carson wrote. ldquoThese were the same as we had seen in pictures from Spain, from Finland, from Poland. ldquoFor all their national dferences their circumstances were now the same and they had that same look in the eyes ndash that stunned, numb look. And by the same cause ndash war.Many areas of Glasgow ndash Tradeston, Scotstoun, Partick, Hyndland, Kelvindale ndash also took direct hits over the two nights, and  people were killed. On the Sunday, in Hyndland, a boy of , whose name was Stanley Ewing, was found in the rubble that had once been his home. He was dressed in his pyjamas in a recessed bed his rescuers heard his voice long after they had assumed that no-one in the pile of debris could be alive.By a stroke of luck, a bag of sugar had been thrown into his bed from a cupboard when the house collapsed around him. The sugar was all he had to eat in the two days since. He was pulled from the wreckage, black with soot and dust but, in the words of one rescuer, ldquosurprisingly cheerful. ldquoIrsquom okay, he told them. ldquoWhen you get me out Irsquoll tell you where my mother and sister are. An -year-old girl was extricated from the wreckage.In Clydebank, in Glasgow, many other people were pulled from their devastated homes. One woman, trapped for six days, was brought out alive by a doctor and demolition workers, but died a few hours later in hospital.On March  two men, one of them a War Reserve policemen, were found, alive, in wreckage in Peel Street, Partick. John Cormack, , was found lying in a bed: a large wooden beam supported the weight of the debris above him. Only his face and arms were visible to his rescuers, who were understandably astonished when he gave them a feeble wave.Moving as quickly and as gently as possible, they shted the debris that had been trapping him. ldquoCould you go a cup of tea , asked Dr Ian A Mackay, who had been summoned to the scene. ldquoAye, ah could fine, Cormack replied. The fact that he had been beneath his blankets probably meant that he did not die from exposure.Later, he told reporters: ldquoI was in bed when I heard the bomb coming. I pulled the bedclothes over me. A crash followed, and the next thing I remember was finding myself buried with the bedclothes still wrapped around me. I had no idea how long I lay. The time passed fairly quickly, and occasionally I heard tappings and voices which seemed to be coming from a distance.It took three hoursrsquo painstaking work to free the other man, Fred Clarke, . A chest of drawers had apparently fallen over his body, too, protecting him from the mass of stone and timber above. Norman Manson, a joiner in charge of the rescue squad, said: ldquoWe had to smash in a floor and crawl underneath to locate the trapped constable. I estimate that we had to remove seven tons of wreckage before we were able to break a way through to him.Glasgowrsquos Lord Provost, Sir Patrick Dollan, launched a fund for the relief of Clydeside air-raid distress. Within three days it had raised pound, by March  the figure had climbed to pound,, including a donation of pound, by John Brownrsquos to a Central Fund.Still the bombing continued. An estimated  people were killed on the night of April  , when bombs fell everywhere: Largs, Greenock, Gretna, and such parts of Glasgow as Shawlands and Hyndland. A German bomber, ing home, dropped a stick of seven high-explosive bombs over part of Falkirk: a six-strong Home Guard patrol was blown of their feet by the blast and showered with mud.Eight people lost their lives in Greenock on April . ldquoBut the last and, in their own way, most terrible German raids on Clydeside began early on Tuesday  May, writes John MacLeod: Maryhill, Yoker, Kilmarnock, and many other places. Not even douce Cardross escaped, taking ldquoan assault of astonishing ferocity.The merciless bombing continued on the night of May  : Greenock suffered horribly, with around  people losing their lives. The two nightsrsquo bombing also claimed the lives of  people in Paisley and  in Port Glasgow.ldquoWhen the sirens went off around pm we went up to the shelter on Whinhill and the bombers came over. We had to come out of the shelter at one point. The distillery was bombed and whisky was running down Bakers Brae on fire! It was a sea of flames, recollected one Greenock woman, just  at the time, on the BBCrsquos WW Peoplersquos War page. A man who was working at Scottrsquos dry dock in the town that night remembered: ldquoThere were a destroyer and a submarine in the dry dock and the sub was knocked off its blocks.The Luftwaffe ed to London on May -, dropping  tons of high explosive and more than , incendiaries. Nearly , civilians died,On April , , it was, yet again, Aberdeenrsquos turn to suffer. ldquoIn the space of just  minutes,  bombs fell, damaging or destroying more than , homes and killing  civilians and  soldiers. Even though Aberdeen was the most frequently bombed city in Britain between  and  ndash a statistic that prompted the nickname Siren City ndash the scale and severity of that nightrsquos Luftwaffe raid shocked everyone. These words come from an article in the city newspaper, the Press and Journal, in September .Aberdeen, writes John MacLeod, was bombed  times during the war, though the figure of  is frequently quoted. Peterhead was bombed  times, Fraserburgh almost as many. Nowhere seemed safe.EIGHTdecades later, when you study photographs of the impact of the Blitz in Scotland, you find yourself looking at the same kind of images, again and again and again: facades of villas and tenements torn away, exposing interior walls, settees, bookcases and light-fittings rescue scenes illuminated by arc-lights families and young children with suitcases in devastated, once-familiar streets colossal piles of rubble. They bring home, just as powerfully as the first-hand testimonies and descriptions mentioned here, the stark horror of what befell Scotland eight decades ago.Some , people lost their lives in Scotland during the Blitz. Across the whole of the UK, the figure was in excess of ,.In March , the nineteenth anniversary of the attacks on Glasgow and Clydebank, John Cormack, the man who had lain trapped for eight days and nights in Peel Street, spoke to The Bulletin, our sister paper. He had spent time in a convalescent hospital, where he met the nurse who would later become his we. Once he had recovered, he joined the Navy."I dont know how youd put it", he said, "but you could say I had faith in coming out alive."I couldnt panic, because I couldnt move. If Id been able to crawl about I might have lost control of my mind. But there I was in my bed, with only my mind free, and after the first shock I settled down to wait for my rescue".Sources: Glasgow Herald archives Blitz article by Tom McKendrick at https:www.west-dunbarton.gov.uk https:www.tommckendrick  River of Fire, by John MacLeod Britainrsquos War: Into Battle -, by Daniel Todman National Records of Scotland Untold Stories: Remembering Clydebank in Wartime, Clydebank Le Story Group  Imperial War Museum website, iwm.org.uk Voices from the Twentieth Century: The Battle of Britain and the Blitz, ed. Nigel Fountain.

title: new-heights-idiocy-gilded-cage
story: The Daily MailStephen Glover said it had been a week in which in many parts of the UK it is deemed inexcusable to question any allegation uttered by Meghan because she is a person of mixed race.He said an online article by the British fashion journalist Hamish Bowles in American Vogue had, however, lsquoreached new heights of idiocy.rsquoldquoBowles suggested that the use of the word lsquonigglingrsquo in a headline above a piece Sarah Vine wrote about the Sussexes in  had some sort of racist intent, he said. ldquoHe is of course thinking of the N-word with which lsquonigglingrsquo has some phonetic similarities though it is etymologically distinct, being of Scandinavian origin according to my Oxford English Dictionary. The word lsquonigglersquo didnrsquot appear in her story and was used only in the headline.He doesnrsquot mind what Bowles thinks of the British press, he added, but does mind very much when lsquoreason is suspended and the truth is deliberately distorted to demonise a newspaper and a blameless journalist.rsquoThe Leo McKinstry described the interview as inflammatory and vindictive.ldquoAs the fallout continues, Republicans are emboldened and the Labour Party has called for a public inquiry into the Duke and Duchessrsquos unsubstantiated allegations of bigotry, he said. ldquoGiven her craving for attention, Meghan Markle will probably be thrilled at this outcome. She had the starring role in the biggest global drama of our age.He said the fundamental problem with the Duchess of Sussex was the conflict between her ambition as a ruthless social climber and the reality of her duties as a relative of the Sovereign.ldquoIf compassion is really her driving force, as she constantly claims, why is her le littered with the social wreckage of fall-outs and feuds , he asked. ldquoThe House of Windsor is just the latest target of her capricious antipathy.The IndependentAnri Wheeler said, having married into a lsquosecretive, patriarchal family business that owns a retail empirersquo, much of what Meghan said felt familiar.ldquoThe Cult provided me two bodyguards, but what I needed was emotional support transitioning into a le detached from my previous reality, she said. ldquoI cried a lot, alone in the largest apartment Irsquod ever lived in, watching Law  Order reruns just to see New York City, my home. It was a gilded cage.She said that when news of Megxit broke friends texted her to say she was following in her footsteps.Now, the depth of her anguish is clear, how unwilling the Firm was to help, she said.ldquoI am grateful she got out. I got out too, and continue to model for my girls that itrsquos never too late to reclaim the parts of yourself larger systems can silence.ldquoI see the ways Meghan is doing the same.

title: neighbourhood-watch-country-life-rosemary-goring
story: A week or so later the van ed, presumably with a dferent driver, and once more prowled up and down, like TV licence patrollers in days of yore.Lest you think I do nothing but stare out of the window, like neighbourhood watch, you would not be entirely wrong. In the depths of winter, the kitchen table is the warmest place to work.It has the advantage of being near the boiler, and the disadvantage thatanything goes on outside ndash an icicle forming, a blackbird alighting on a branch ndash it is easy to be distracted.Now that spring is here, I am back in my study upstairs, where work proceeds faster, but the doings of the village pass wholly unobserved. Morris dancers could be digging ots on the village green and Irsquod know nothing about it. ROSEMARY: Dunblane memories will never fadeAs I sat down to write this, two white horses plodded past, a perfect pair that ought to be pulling a carriage. They were followed by a glossy carthorse, heading the other way. Unlike a young rider yesterday, who was scrolling her phone as she rode at a snailrsquos pace, these equestrians have all their wits about them. I mention this flurry of four-legged traffic because the Christmas before last I was given a copy of the experimental French novelist Georges Perecrsquos book, An Attempt at Exhausting a Place in Paris.Perec was no ordinary writer. He once wrote a long novel without using the letter e. Imagin how hard that must hav bn. In October, , he spent a long weekend in ious cafeacutes in Saint-Sulpice, a district near Saint-Germain where I have stayed a few times. His book is a prosaic record of who and what passes by during his vigils: lsquoIt is five to six. A man took out a dolly from a blue van, loaded it with dferent cleaning products, and pushed it down rue des Canettes. Outside you can barely even make out the faces anymorehellip An almost empty  goes by. A police car goes by and turns in front of the church square. An empty  and a moderately full  go by. The bells of Saint-Sulpice begin to ringhelliprsquo Perec came to the conclusion that he had missed his vocation, as ticket collector for the Paris City Transport Authority.Having often stopped for coffee in the same cafeacutes, I thought Irsquod put in a sht at our kitchen window. It was a Friday morning. Before breakfast, an oil tanker had called at neighbours, whose previous delivery had been wrongly apportioned between Aga tank and central heating, leaving them at risk of freezing. A teenage girl had set off for the school bus shortly thereafter, with a heavy bag on her shoulder.It was a quarter past ten when I settled with a notebook, the sun so bright I had to squint. The early morning frost had long since burned off. Cars around the green were flashing in the brilliance. Normally at this time of year theyrsquod be coated in mud, but these days theyrsquore hardly used. Herersquos what happened:. Woman from the other end of the village s from walking a neighbourrsquos dogs, a young black Labrador, and an elderly golden retriever.Carer emerges in a mask from a house, her plastic apron billowing. She drives off.A blue car, young man at wheel. The new mph limit means you have time to see whorsquos driving.A x, the same model as once reversed into us in Achiltibuie, crushing the bonnet.White car passes, too fast. Therersquos much consternation in Hoolet at the speed people drive. When there was a ramp for roadworks last autumn, a young father of two heard a speedster race over it in his souped-up motor, followed by a crunch as something in the undercarriage disintegrated.. Local shuttlebus passes, driver like a white-beaked puffin in his mask. One passenger, seats cordoned off by red and white tape.. Farm trailer with dead sheep, hooves in air.Young woman, wearing earbuds, walking a spaniel.. Van from the donkey sanctuary.Woman not dressed for Saint-Germain knocks on a neighbourrsquos door.Wee car the colour of sludge.Black car with Whistlerrsquos mother at the wheel.. Car the colour of cregraveme de menthe.Van that reconditions electrical appliances.Farm trailer minus dead sheep.Red car.Yellow van.Man holding phone wearing black mask and camouflage jacket hurrying across the green.. Neighbour pulling up dead foliage by her front door.. Volkswagen repair van.. Professional dog walkerrsquos van parks, and four dferent breeds leap out. Please donrsquot come near our grasshellipYou can see why Georges Perec preferred the city. There were times during that Hoolet hour when it felt asthe world had frozen. Even the birds were AWOL, perhaps sensing surveillance.Fridays are often busy with local shops delivering sirloin steak, groceries and prescriptions. Throughout the week supermarket vans come and go. In fact, while I was at the window, a woman posted on the village Facebook page that Tesco had wrongly delivered cat litter. Any takers But on this of all mornings, nothing of note occurred. I suppose I shouldnrsquot be so disappointed. After all, despite the crowds thronging the Paris streets, nothing spectacular happened on Perecrsquos watch either. And that, it seems, was the point. He had gone in search of the lsquoinfraordinaryrsquo, or lsquowhat happens when nothing happens.rsquo What he found was not drama, but rhythm, the humdrum turning of the dayrsquos wheel. ROSEMARY: New spring, same old covidWhat he also proved was that you can capture the personality of an area by naming the pieces of the jigsaw. Unexciting though inidual parts might be, the accumulation of detail creates a picture larger and more colourful than its parts. During Perecrsquos three-day watch, the series of uneventful happenings builds into a vivid scene.In Hoolet, it might require longer than an hour staring into the street to give a full flavour of what itrsquos like to live here. In that respect, it is no dferent from Saint-Sulpice.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of the Herald.

title: national-museums-hunt-coronavirus-exhibits
story: Now, the historic riches held by the National Museum of Scotland are to be boosted by a new lsquoCovid collectionrsquo which curators hope will include supermarket signs warning of toilet roll shortages and posters urging tourists to stay away from beauty spots.Evenmost people living through the Covid- crisis may prefer to forget it, the idea is to give future generations the opportunity to see how it has shaped and changed our lives.Curators from the Edinburgh-based museum have been gathering pieces from across the country which illustrate lockdown, the fight against coronavirus and the vaccination programme since the beginning of the health crisis.Among the items are some which may be regarded as throwaway and day to day detritus, but which experts say sum up how Scots responded to the pandemic - such as homemade face masks, sanitiser, hopeful lsquorainbowrsquo paintings and warning posters.There will also be items which show the role of health, emergency and military professionals throughout the pandemic, and others which demonstrate the economic impact, community response and emotional toll Covid- has had on patients and their families. Once gathered, the lsquoCovid collectionrsquo will become permanently held within the national museum archives alongside other treasured artefacts from Scotlandrsquos history, to be used for exhibitions and displays far in the future.She said the museum is now in a race against time to gather pandemic-related items before they too are lost.ldquoAt the time of Ebola, we struggled to get signs at airports, they were not seen as material that was important or should be kept.ldquoOne thing that we might have already missed out on because of how fast things moved, were signs at supermarkets limiting the amount of toilet rolls that people could buy.ldquoItrsquos one thing that people remember, and we would have liked one of those.The collection is being split into six categories: public health, hospitals and treatment politics economy tourism education and everyday le.Among the first objects to be collected was a face shield made by a teacher at Lochaber High School using a D printer and finished with plastic  which was delivered to the local Belford hospital by Lochaber Mountain Rescue Team. The item is said to illustrate the impact of the pandemic on the NHS, PPE shortages, the community response and school closures.Other items include Hidden Disabilitiesrsquo sunflower lanyards and facemask exemption cards, and handknitted hearts which were distributed among Covid- patients and their loved ones at Glasgow intensive care units to help create a link between them at a time when hospital visiting was not allowed.One heart would be placed in the palm of an intensive care patient and the other given to a relative, to help forge an invisible and personal bond.The role of the army in helping with its installation and the cooperation with civilian agencies is also said to be of interest within the context of the museumrsquos military collections.At the other end of the spectrum, the curators are gathering symbols of happiness and hope that helped raise spirits during the darkest days ndash including a painted pebbled from a Shetland beach.She added: ldquoWe are being very selective, there is so much that we could collect - covid has shaped the world around us in many ways that we donrsquot think about.ldquoSuch as people who gave birth during the pandemic, who kept the masks they were wearing during that time to go alongside the babyrsquos mementos like name bracelets from hospital. Thatrsquos such a defining symbol of their experience, and these throwaway things have been kept.The collection will reflect Scotland as a whole, in the hope of showing future generations how dferent areas of the country responded to the crisis.ldquoWe want to show how lockdown has been experienced in dferent parts of the country, and how that experience ies because of culture and geological factors added Sarah.ldquoOne thing we would like have are the signs that appeared on the outside of villages in summer which rely heavily on the tourism industry, asking visitors to respect that the community was self-isolated and they were closed.ldquoWe saw that in relation to first lockdown as a way to quarantine in rural area. Signs were put up by iniduals, and there is a spectrum of dferent languages and dialects - some played with the Gaelic language.ldquoWe would love one of these signs they are still in use, but therersquos a waiting game with some of this material.The National Museum of Scotland is one of many around the world which has announced it is collecting coronavirus-related items to help explain the pandemic to people in years to come.Last week The Smithsonian National Museum of American History said it had acquired the vial that contained the first dose of Covid- vaccine administered in the United States as part of its plans to document the global pandemic and ldquothis extraordinary period we were going through.Meanwhile, Glasgow Museums, including the Riverside transport museum, has also said it is collecting pandemic items with a view to future exhibitions.Among the objects being gathered are examples of childrenrsquos lockdown schoolwork, posters relating to cancelled events and artworks which depict key workers.Sarah added: ldquoWe sometimes have a job telling people that we collect things from the present as well as the past - they think a museum is related to historic objects.ldquoBut everyone we have approached has realised these things have value, even when itrsquos not a terribly obvious object, people instantly understand why itrsquos of historic value.

title: big-read-final-resting-place-father-capitalism-adam-smith-resurrected-scottish-slavery-debate
story: It doesnrsquot look controversial at first. But look a little bit closer. In places, the words are hard to read ndash theyrsquore a bit faded after a couple of hundred years of Edinburgh wind and rain ndash but you can just about make them out. ldquoHere are deposited the remains of the author of The Theory of Moral Sentiments and The Wealth of Nations. He was born th June  and died on th July .No more than that. No long tribute. No quotation from the Bible. No great lines from his books. Just his name: Adam Smith.He is, undoubtedly, the most famous person buried in this place, the graveyard of Canongate Kirk on the Royal Mile, just up from the Scottish Parliament.No-one really remembers Robert Keith, author of A History of the Church and State in Scotland from the Reformation to , or Professor Charles Alston, lecturer in botany at Edinburgh University, or Horatius Bonar, preacher and writer of hymns, or any of the others who are buried here.But everyone remembers Adam Smith.He is the most famous economist who ever lived.Fans and apostles of the great man, and historians and curious people interested in the Scottish Enlightenment, still visit the grave, but, unexpectedly, it has now become a source of controversy.Tomorrow, a body called the Edinburgh Slavery and Colonialism Legacy Review Group will meet to look at a provisional list of monuments, places, and place names which could be investigated for their association with slavery and the empire. Adam Smithrsquos grave is on the list.The review group was formed last year by Edinburgh City Council in response to the Black Lives Matter protests with the aim of investigating sites in Edinburgh that might have links with slavery, including statues, monuments, and street names. The grouprsquos purpose, according to the council, was to recommend what needed to be done to ldquorecty the glorication of slavery and colonialism which the statues and other sites represent to many people.The group will report by the end of the year.lsquoNot prejudicialrsquoThe leader of the committee, Sir Geoff Palmer, professor emeritus in le sciences at Heriot-Watt University, has specically said he doesnrsquot want any statues to be taken down ndash ldquothe next statue down in our country should be racism, he has said ndash and that his preferred method is education and information.He would like Scottish people to understand their history better. He says: ldquoWersquore going to provide people with information about their city. That information will not be prejudicial, it is there to give the public information about the city and its links with slavery and colonialism.However, the inclusion of Smithrsquos grave on the list, which was leaked to The , has not gone down well. The historian Sir Tom Devine said he disagreed with a gravestone being treated in such a way. He also questioned the idea that Smith thought slavery was a fact of le, which was the apparent justication for including his grave on the list.Sir Tom said it was abundantly clear that Smith believed slavery was evil and inhumane.The question is: should we be surprised by any of this  Adam Smith, and his beliefs, have been misunderstood, or misappropriated, for quite a long time now.Thatcherrsquos praiseNOT only is it apparently being suggested that he was an apologist for slavery, he has often been described as the patron saint of capitalism or a cheerleader for the pursuit of self-interest, a kind of king of neoliberals. It also doesnrsquot particularly help his reputation with some modern audiences that one of his greatest fans was Margaret Thatcher.But Thatcher herself knew Smithrsquos philosophy was much subtler than the popular image. He did say self-interest was the underlying principle of economic le and famously wrote that ldquoit is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker that we expect our dinner, but from their regard to their own self-interest.But, as Thatcher pointed out, he also wrote about our instinct to help others. ldquoTo feel much for others and little for ourselves, he said, ldquoto restrain our selfish, and to indulge our benevolent affections, constitutes the perfection of human nature.What Smith was doing, really, was observing human nature and the fact that people are fundamentally self-interested, but it goes deeper than that.Russ Roberts, economist and author of How Adam Smith Can Change Your Le, believes Smith laid down some principles that can be applied to modern le and even help us to live better.He argues that Smithrsquos lesser-known book The Theory of Moral Sentiments ndash one of the titles inscribed on his gravestone ndash can be a kind of self-help book. In answer to the question ldquowhat did Adam Smith ever do for us , Robertsrsquos answer would be ldquomore than you think.Roberts sums it up this way: itrsquos kind of shocking, he says, to realise that the person we know as the father of economics didnrsquot think the pursuit of wealth was a very good idea, he thought it was corrosive, he thought it was bad for you, he thought ambition was bad for you, he thought the pursuit of fame would destroy your character and your happiness, your serenity and your tranquillity, and itrsquos all there in his book The Theory of Moral Sentiments.The book, which was first published in , is largely forgotten and unread now ndash overshadowed by its more famous brother The Wealth of Nations ndash but Roberts believes that, in its mix of economics, philosophy, and psychology, there are real gems of truth about wealth, fame and ambition.One of Smithrsquos ideas, for instance, is the concept of the ldquoimpartial spectator, a kind of inner voice that can tell us whatrsquos right and wrong, and guide our behaviour imagine, he says, that you are being judged not by God but by another human being.Roberts believes this concept of the impartial spectator can be useful in modern le. Speaking to Reason magazine, he said the idea is an interesting way to think about your behaviour: ldquoTo step outside yourself and say, lsquoin this setting, is my outrage really justied when Irsquom working myself into a state over some inconvenience or some lsquoinjusticersquo  would an outsider whorsquos not me think that rsquo I think thatrsquos a useful way to step outside yourself and see whatrsquos going on.Roberts believes there are other values in Smithrsquos philosophy that have relevance today, particularly his ldquobig three, the values that he says should guide us all: justice, beneficence, and prudence. Justice means not hurting others, beneficence means being good to others, and prudence means being good to yourself.A principled manTHE prudent man, says Smith, is sincere and honest, hersquos cautious in his speech and doesnrsquot stick his opinion into every discussion hersquos a good friend and his friendships are a ldquofaithful attachment to a few well-tried and well-chosen companions. In the world of social media, thatrsquos not a bad set of principles to stick to.And Roberts says it isnrsquot the only example of Smithrsquos apparent prescience ndash in fact, Roberts believes that, in some ways, the great economist predicted our obsession with the internet, gadgets, and mobile phones.ldquoAdam Smith says, basically, that we fall in love with little conveniences, says Roberts. ldquoHe calls them lsquofrivolous trinkets of utilityrsquo which is really what our gadgets are all about. In particular, of all things, he picks on the watch hellip he makes fun of the fact, and really judges the person who pays a premium for a watch thatrsquos a little more accurate, just because itrsquos kind of amazing and wonderful. But it doesnrsquot make the person any more punctual.ldquoTheyrsquore not more accurate, they just know how inaccurate they are. So, he makes fun of the fact that we love these gadgets.Some might say therersquos a paradox at work in all of this. How can the man famous for writing a book about self-interest and how it makes the world go round also write a book that says that self-interest and self-obsession isnrsquot the only thing that matters But Roberts says Smithrsquos two most famous books are really about very dferent things: The Theory of Moral Sentiments is a book about our personal space and the people we see frequently whereas The Wealth of Nations is about how we behave in the marketplace, a place of impersonal exchange, of strangers.But in both books, Smith is concerned about how we behave rather than how hersquod like us to behave.It is in this context that we should see his views on slavery. In response to the controversy over Smithrsquos grave, Tom Devine drew attention to the lectures the great man delivered on justice, police, revenue and arms in , long before the formal establishment of the abolitionist movement in Britain.In the lectures, Smith describes the treatment of slaves in ancient Rome. At night, he said, ldquonothing was to be heard but the cries of slaves whom their masters were punishing.He also talked about the brutal day-to-day le that slaves must have led, ldquotheir le and their property entirely at the mercy of another, and their liberty,they could be said to have any, at his disposal too.lsquoColonialrsquo sitesWHAT seems to be more problematic ndash and itrsquos this that seems to have led to Smithrsquos grave appearing on the list of ldquocolonial sites in Edinburgh ndash was his pessimism about the chances of abolition.ldquoSlavery, he said, ldquotakes place in all societies at their beginning, and proceeds from that tyrannic disposition which may almost be said to be natural to mankind. It is indeed almost impossible that it should ever be totally or generally abolished.Now, you may think that Smithrsquos views are abhorrent and suggest we must accept slavery as inevitable, or you may think that the existence of modern slavery in the st century proves him right. But the truth is that, as well as being credited with influencing modern economic thinking, Smith is also credited with influencing the anti-slavery movement.William Wilberforce, who met Smith in , quoted him often, and Smithrsquos arguments were included in early anti-slavery material. Strange, then, that a council body looking for sites associated with slavery should zoom in on Adam Smithrsquos grave. Whether the site will make the final list is unclear.Perhaps the review group will listen to the criticism ndash in any case, the decision will be taken tomorrow. But Geoff Palmer, the man who leads the group, knows the subtleties involved. If you start removing things from their context, he says ndash statues, for example ndash in  years we will have forgotten the context.And itrsquos important that we know that context, and the nuances and complexities, because the nuances and complexities cannot always be seen in the words on a gravestone, faded by  years of Edinburgh wind and rain.

title: david-pratt-world-darkness-descending-upon-myanmar
story: For many Burmese it has brought new meaning to the term ldquonight terrors. Online the hashtag #nightdragging is used by many residents among Myanmarrsquos towns and cities to help band together and co-ordinate warnings and resistance to the night-time raids by security forces looking for daytime protesters.It has now been six weeks since the armed forces under General Min Aung Hlaing ousted the elected government of Aung San Suu Kyi, detained her and officials of her National League for Democracyparty, and set up a ruling junta.In the intervening period since the putsch, the country has been plunged into a kind of Orwellian nightmare thatrsquos become real, where disappearances have become the order of the day. The hours of darkness are an especially terrying time for many hunkering down in this long troubled Asian country of  million people.In a message replete with the sort of doublespeak that could have come straight from the pages of George Orwellrsquos dystopian novel Nineteen Eighty-Four, the State Administration Council ndash a title chosen by the coup-makers ndash announced that it was taking away basic civil liberties, allowing for indefinite detention and for the police to search homes with impunity. And in the same vein, the Military Information Unit issued a statement that made a rather duplicitous attempt at explaining the security forces presence across Myanmar.ldquoSecurity forces will be performing day and night security for the public to sleep peacefully in the community, the statement said, evenmost ordinary citizens interpreted this for what it really meant.Despite a crackdown on the internet and online provision by the junta, video and other reports still come out of the country and tell a very dferent story. From two of Myanmarrsquos biggest cities, Yangon and Mandalay, there have been reports of unidentied men at night setting fires to frighten and perhaps provoke residents onto the streets.Videos posted online almost nightly show heavily-armed security forces prowling the streets shooting bullets and tear gas at homes and around residential areas while terried citizens cower at their windows.They also show truckloads of soldiers arriving at households from which suspected protesters and other activists can be seen being beaten and bundled into trucks before their own cars are sometimes also taken away by the army.Threat of arrestIN response, civilians in local neighbourhoods do what they can to resist or warn those in peril of arrest. Some bang pots and pans as early warning signs as the troops fan out in their neighbourhoods while others swarm the streets to try and prevent the arrests.ldquoOur nights arenrsquot safe anymore and ldquoMyanmar military is kidnapping people at night are common captions on messages shared widely online.ldquoThis is an army with a heart of darkness, David Scott Mathieson, an independent analyst who has long studied the practices of the Myanmar military was cited by numerous news outlets as saying a few days ago. ldquoThis is an unrepentant institution, Mathieson added, speaking of the Tatmadaw, as the army is known and which first came to power in a  coup, saying that it had to safeguard national unity.Human rights observers say that with the generals now back running the country the army is using lethal tactics and an arsenal of battlefield weapons to carry out a ldquokilling spree against peaceful protesters who oppose this yearrsquos February  coup.Amid the deteriorating situation, a leading UN expert said the military has likely committed ldquocrimes against humanity in its attempt to stay in power.While stressing that such offences can only be determined in a court of law, Thomas Andrews, the UNrsquos special rapporteur on human rights in Myanmar, said the crimes likely included ldquoacts of murder, enforced disappearance, persecution, torture carried out with ldquothe knowledge of senior leadership, including junta leader General Hlaing.For some Myanmar watchers, though, such behaviour by the army comes as little surprise. Military analysts point to the fact that the Tatmadawrsquos lower ranks have for a long time now been at the sharp end of ethnic wars in the country.During the last three years, the Tatmadaw has waged war intermittently against ethnic rebel armies in three states: Rakhine, Shan, and Kachin.AtrocitiesBATTLEFIELD atrocities include the rape of women and girls, and the use of civilians as human shields have brutalised the same infantrymen that are now patrolling Myanmarrsquos streets.Witnesses in Mandalay recently reported seeing soldiers from the rd Light Infantry Division, which led the deadly campaign against Rohingya Muslims in western Rakhine state in .Rights groups have voiced alarm at the juntarsquos deployment of a unit blamed for atrocities against civilians, including a massacre of  Rohingya men. The US Treasury imposed sanctions against Aung Hlaing, the isionrsquos commander, in .ldquoThese Myanmar military tactics are far from new, but their killing sprees have never before been live-streamed for the world to see, said Joanne Mariner, the director of crisis response at Amnesty International, speaking about the latest crackdown.She was speaking after Amnestyrsquos Crisis Evidence Lab veried the more than  videos of the ongoing crackdown and confirmed that security forces ldquoappear to be implementing planned, systematic strategies including the ramped-up use of lethal force.ldquoMany of the killings documented amount to extrajudicial executions, the rights group said.Meanwhile, the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners , a long-established group that helps political detainees in Myanmar, has warned thatthe military coup is not reversed, then the arbitrary arrests will only increase.ldquoFamily members are left with no knowledge of the charges, location, or condition of their loved ones. These are not isolated incidents, and night-time raids are targeting dissenting voices. It is happening across the country, the AAPP said in a statement.In cracking down so violently, the Tatmadaw has once again cast Myanmar as a pariah state and turning the clock back to the isolationist era that preceded the past decadersquos slow opening in the country.Not surprisingly, there has been deepening international condemnation these past weeks against the coup and military rule, but General Hlaing and his cadres have shown no signs of backing down. Why would they, some ask, when their seizure of power has as much to do with protecting the militaryrsquos sprawling, and highly lucrative, business interests For decades, the generals have amassed fortunes by controlling the state bureaucracy and establishingnear-monopolies in key sectors.Through two highly shadowy military-controlled giants, Myanmar Economic Holdings Limitedand the Myanmar Economic Corporation , it is estimated that at least  companies in the country are wholly or partially overseen by generals, according to a report by Justice For Myanmar , a covert group of activists who campaign for justice and accountability.Such conglomerates control businesses and investments in sectors ranging from beer, tobacco and consumables to mines, mills, tourism, property development and telecommunications.Much of the lucrative ndash and largely unregulated ndash jade and ruby trade is controlled by military-owned businesses.Jewel controlSINCE , the disaster-prone jade industry has remained ldquocontrolled by a network of military elites, drug lords and their cronies, according to NGO Global Witness that tracks corruption and exploitation.Although Myanmar is the worldrsquos largest producer of jade, and the trade is estimated to be worth billions of dollars a year, only a very small part of the financial windfall ends up in state coffers with most high-quality stones believed to be smuggled over the border into China.Indeed, Chinarsquos closeness with the Myanmar couprsquos generals and its reluctance to condemn their takeover stems, say analysts, from Beijingrsquos substantial vested economic interests in Myanmar.Ruling for nearly half a century, ldquothe military top brass had time to enrich themselves, said Francoise Nicolas, Asia director of the French Institute of International Relations. The brief stint of quasi-civilian rule from   did little to change that. But the military may have feared for its future prospects after Suu Kyirsquos party won by a landslide in November, Nicolas told Agence France Presserecently.ldquoThis risked endangering part of their wealth and was very probably part of their decision to launch a putsch, she added.The junta, however, appears determined that the world interprets the situation very dferently. So determined, in fact, that it has hired an Israeli-Canadian lobbyist who will be paid  million to ldquoassist in explaining the real situation of the armyrsquos coup to the US and other countries, according to documents filed with the US government.Ari Ben-Menashe and his firm, Dickens  Madson Canada, will represent Myanmarrsquos military government in Washington, and lobby Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Israel, and Russia, as well as international bodies like the United Nations, according to a consultancy agreement, Reuters news agency reported.Ben-Menashersquos client portfolio ndash which has included late Zimbabwean leader Robert Mugabe ndash has drawn attention before. But by working with Myanmarrsquos military, legal experts say he risks violating US sanctions imposed on top generals.ResettlementBEN-MENASHE told Reuters his task was to convince Washington that Myanmarrsquos generals wanted to move closer to the West and away from China. He said they wanted to resettle Rohingya Muslims who fled a  assault for which the UN has accused the military of overseeing a genocide. Few human rights observers, however, believe Ben-Menashe has any chance of persuading the Americans.ldquoIt is highly implausible that he could convince the United States of the narrative hersquos proposing, said John Ston, Asia advocacy director at Human Rights Watch.Meanwhile, as all these geopolitical machinations continue, so too do the dark deeds being enacted on the street of Myanmarrsquos town and cities.Alongside the armyrsquos paranoid and uncompromising worldview, it has only intensied its repressive campaign against its own citizens.
