title: Closing date nears over Irish Street development
story: THE planned redevelopment of the former Irish Street police station site in Downpatrick takes an important step forward next month.That is when developers will be formally asked to submit their bids to redevelop the site which stretches as far back at St Patrickrsquos Avenue and also includes a number of empty buildings adjacent to the former police base and the Irish Street car park.Five developers and  community groups have expressed an interest in the site with its regeneration being spearheaded by the Department for Communitiesand Newry, Mourne and Down Council.A draft development brief mdash paving the way for the regeneration of the sprawling site mdash is expected to be formally signed off shortly, once lawyers for the government department and local authority have had an opportunity to examine and approve it.Developers will then be given up to  weeks to submit their proposals with a final assessment made around September, leading to the selection of a preferred bidder who will be responsible for all planning and construction costs.Once a developer has been selected, he will be given a year to secure planning approval and to complete the regeneration of the site within three years.Moving forward, there is an acknowledgement that the current Irish Street car is badly laid out and that the redevelopment proposal provides an opportunity to address this, paving the way for it to be used for future events, markets and festivals, with the DfC and local council prepared to provide additional funding to allow this to happen.Some members of a working group, which includes council and DfC officials, Downpatrick councillors and business community representatives, are also keen to see work carried out to help make Downpatrick town centre pedestrian friendly to help ldquoencourage creativity and attract more visitors.During a recent meeting of the group it was confirmed that it is hoped to retain all the spaces at the car park and also redevelop the facility into a welcoming feature.The working group will also be given the first opportunity to review the scheme proposed by the chosen developer which is designed to regenerate the heart of the town centre.An entrance to the development site from Lynn Doyle Place has been suggested, with the developer encouraged to engage with residents who live at this part of the town.Signicantly, developers interested in the prime town centre site are being asked to focus on how their chosen scheme can potentially contribute to Downpatrickrsquos night-time economy post Covid, providing a boost for residents and help attract visitors to Downpatrick.While it has also been suggested extending the perimeter of the regeneration site this has been ruled out as a non-starter as it would serve to delay the planned redevelopment.In the near future, as part of continuing work on the Irish Street revitalisation programme, graphics will appear on the front of the former police base, while the archway at the entrance to the Irish Street car park will be painted.A progress report on the Irish Street scheme was outlined at Mondayrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee and has been welcomed by Cllr Dermot Curran.He said he hopes the timetable which has been outlined will be realised to provide a major boost to the social and economic regeneration of Downpatrick town centre and has welcomed the emphasis on helping revive the night time economy.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThe opportunity to redevelop a huge swathe of town centre land will not happen again and it is important that we get it right for everyonersquos benefit. The redevelopment plan has the potential to provide a boost for existing traders who have been at the heart of the town centre economy for decades.News of progress to redevelop the town centre site comes after recent confirmation that the location is one of a number of high profile schemes included in a real estate portfolio designed to attract potential national and international developers and investors.Newry, Mourne and Down is one of five local councils which are part of the Belfast Region City Deal consortium and is hoping for a share of a near poundbn Treasury and Northern Ireland Executive investment package.As work to secure city deal funding continues, the local authorities which form the consortiumhave come together to launch a new portfolio of real estate development opportunities within their respective areas with the aim of attracting global investment, boosting tourism and creating sustainable regeneration.The Irish Street regeneration proposal is one of  schemes being showcased in the so-called Belfast Region Investment Guide which have been identied by the ious councils. The portfolio details potential uses for each site with the guide used to market the development opportunities to developers and investors, both locally and overseas.City Deal members say the compilation of the portfolio is the next step in the progression of the consortium with the overriding aim of creating more and better jobs and attracting investment.Newry, Mourne and Down is hoping to secure money from the city deal for a multi-million pound flagship tourism project in Newcastle, with the so-called Mournes Gateway proposal a series of ambitious projects which includes a gondola ride into the heart of the Mourne mountains..prettyPhoto

title: Council 159% rates rises third lowest in province
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has imposed the third lowest rates rise in Northern Ireland.The above inflation .% hike to fund the local authorityrsquos poundm budget was unanimously agreed last week by local politicians who described the increase as ldquofair and balanced.New figures confirm that the rise was the the third lowest across the provincersquos  councils, while three local authorities mdash Antrim and Newtownabbey, Lisburn and Castlereagh and Mid Ulster mdash froze their district rate.The smallest increase of .% was made by Mid and East Antrim Council with the second lowest imposed by Fermanagh and Omagh Council mdash .%.With Newry, Mourne and Down in third spot in terms of the lowest increase, fourth place went to Derry City and Strabane Council which increased its rate by .%.Belfast City Council hiked rates by .%, while Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon sanctioned a .% rates rise. Ards and North Down Council agreed a .% rise, which equates to an extra pound a month for ratepayers.The highest increase of .% was imposed by Causeway Coast and Glens Council will see average household bills increase by pound..The majority of councils have have agreed to increase annual rates bills which are calculated by combining the district rate which they set with the regional rate set by Stormont.While the Northern Ireland Executive has frozen the regional rate for households and businesses for the coming year, Stormont finance minister, Conor Murphy, has outlined a poundm rates support to businesses in the new financial year. He had also urged local authorities to also freeze their district rates.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is to create two new funds to help the district recover from the devastating impact of the coronavirus.The Covid revitalisation fund is designed to help the business community, with the local authority also establishing an economic recovery reserve as the district plots its way out of the global pandemic.The local authorityrsquos budget for the new financial year represents an increase of pound.m on last year with the rates rise meaning that homeowners with a property valued at pound, will be paying pound. more a year or  pence a month.The organisation also has poundm in its cash reserve.Politicians say the .% increase is needed to cover the cost of delivering economic regeneration, planning services, leisure and community facilities, refuse collection and street cleansing across the district over the next year.Council chief executive, Marie Ward, said when the organisation struck last yearrsquos district rate, it had no concept of the challenges it would face over the following  months due to the global pandemic.She said Covid- had presented ldquosignicant financial challenges to all councils, with Newry, Mourne and Down no exception.Mrs Ward said the local authority was able to sustain many services and play a key role in responding to the pandemic, moving quickly to make its services safe.ldquoWhether it is supporting businesses through virtual workshops, helping residents stay active or connected during lockdown, working with community partners to get help to our most vulnerable residents, or carrying out environmental improvements works in our towns and villages, we have not stood still, she said.With infection numbers reducing and the coronavirus vaccination programme gathering increasing pace, Mrs Ward said that ldquoambitious thinking is required now more, welcoming progress on major plans to regenerate the district which will help bolster the local economy.The chief executive said the local authority has progressed business cases for both the Newry City Centre Regeneration and Gateway to the Mournes projects, while working with its Belfast Region City Deal partners, on progressing number of regional innovation and skills programmes which will produce benefits for the district..prettyPhoto

title: Covid cases increase locally
story: DOWNPATRICK and Ardglass are included in a list of  postcode areas in Northern Ireland which have recorded the highest number of new coronavirus cases between March  and .Out of  people tested,  positive cases were confirmed on Monday by the Department of Health.The news comes after visitors again flocked to Newcastle and other popular beauty spots across the district last weekend, but the numbers in some other areas were not as high as reported the previous Saturday and Sunday.Police confirmed that last Sunday that they were made aware of reports of traffic congestion and parked cars causing an obstruction within the vicinity of the Trassey Road and Burrenreagh Road near Bryansford.There were also issues at the Bloody Bridge area on the outskirts of the town with a number of tickets issues to drivers for causing an obstruction, while cars were prevented from entering Castlewellan Forest Park on Sunday afternoon for a period as paramedics and the air ambulance crew responded to a medical emergency.Police had promised that they would be providing a ldquovisible presence in the Newcastle area in particular and had asked motorists to adhere to the designated parking areas provided. Cars parks across the resort were full for most of the weekend.People who live in the resort are particularly concerned that with the deadly coronavirus still in circulation, such a large influx of visitors has implications for public health.Local politicians had also highlighted the need for people to continue exercising social distancing and adhering to public health advice, insisting that there was no room for complacency at this crucial time, despite and increase in positive Covid cases across the district and the roll-out of a comprehensive vaccination programme.Senior Newry, Mourne and Down Council officials had met with police ahead of another anticipated busy weekend in a bid to signicantly reduce the number of visitors, with council officials placing cones in the Tollymore and Bryansford areas, with others located at Carrick Little near Slieve Binnian and in the Mournes.In addition, police set up a number of rolling checkpoints on the main approach roads to Newcastle last weekend, with officers also deployed in the heart of the resort.Police also managed parking at the hugely popular Bloody Bridge area on the outskirts of the resort, expressing concern that some drivers had shown little care or attention for pedestrians or other road users by the way they had parked their vehicles, one of which was a Transit van.Mournes councillor, Willie Clarke, has praised the response from PSNI, local council, the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership, the emergency services and others for their response to managing visitors to main tourism hotspots.He said there was a greater presence on the ground which has been welcomed by residents following the ldquodangerous level of visitors who flocked to Newcastle and other ious parts of the district the previous weekend.ldquoI welcome the co-operation between all the ious agencies to improve the safety of residents, continued Cllr Clarke.ldquoThe local council placed traffic cones in a number of areas popular with visitors, while the PSNIhad vehicle checkpoints at main arterial routes into Newcastle area. There were also a number of mobile police patrols in the resort, with tickets issued to motorists for causing an obstruction at a number of areas including the Trassey Track and Bloody Bridge.Cllr Clarke said these measures helped ease the pressures on what he described as ldquonatural environmental treasurers as the district moves into the Covid recovery phase.He added: ldquoIt is clear that extra resources are required to manage and maintain our rights of ways, forests, beaches and our parks. The local council and PSNI will continue to share social media messaging on restricting travel to within  miles, with police confirming that they will continue to remain active across the entire district, not just Newcastle.Many people took to social media after another busy weekend to ask why visitors from outside the district who had travelled quite a few miles were not stopped and sent home. Under current coronavirus regulations, people are advised not to travel more than  miles from their homes..prettyPhoto

title: Drumaness mum launches sensory toys business
story: A DRUMANESS mother of a severely disabled boy has used her time spent shielding her family throughout the pandemic to launch a new sensory box business.Louise Gartland has been inundated with orders for the boxes containing stimulating items tailored for each childrsquos sensory needs.The  year-old carer needed to shield with her two sons, aged four and two, as her eldest son, Riley, requires around-the-clock care.While carers come in to help with wheelchair user Riley, Louise found le dficult after shielding started as like many people who needed to shield, felt so isolated.ldquoI would already have been isolated with Riley being so vulnerable to illness and as soon as lockdown happened that was an additional isolation for me, she says.ldquoBecause I wasnrsquot able to go out at all, it had a detrimental effect on my mental health and that affected the whole family too. So I started to think about what I could do and this is where the business came from.After  years of working with adults with learning disabilities, Louise came up with the idea of creating sensory boxes.ldquoRiley is registered blind and is deaf, so he needs a lot of sensory input. I came up with the idea of providing affordable sensory toys and products for children who need them, explained Louise.ldquoAs a special needs mum, I find thatyou go online to find sensory toys, they are hugely expensive.ldquoIrsquove spent four years buying stuff for Riley and I have a good idea of the things that you wouldnrsquot necessarily buy as a sensory product, but that will provide a similar sensory experience.ldquoI tailor my boxes to the child and find out about their sensory needs to determine what type of things would help them, such tactile items or fidget stuff to help with concentration and children who are hyperactive, or visually stimulating items such as light-up toys, calming products or growing products for a darkened room. There are so many sensory needs out there.Louise has been supported from the Go For It Programme in association with Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The programme is part funded by Invest Northern Ireland and the European Regional Development Fund under the Investment for Growth and Jobs Northern Irelandprogramme.Louise sells mostly through her Facebook page and word of mouth recommendations.ldquoI put up a post on Shop Ireland and I wasnrsquot really expecting the numbers of responses that I got. In the run-up to Christmas I had  orders. I had to turn people away, she explained.The support of the Go For It programme was a key part of the impetus to get the business up and running.The programme is delivered free of charge by a team of experienced business mentors through Northern Irelandrsquos wide network of enterprise agencies and provides expert advice and help with developing a robust business plan to help turn ideas into a commercial enterprise.Louise joined the Go For It scheme through Down Business Centre and was able to access training.ldquoIt gave me the expertise in what to concentrate on first - I went and saw the accountant and got registered, she says.ldquoI was a bit apprehensive because I had absolutely no business experience, just a good idea. But the project gave me the reassurance that it was a good idea and we have put together a business plan.ldquoJoan OrsquoHara has helped me massively throughout the last few months and continues to be available for guidance should I need it or would recommend the best people to talk to in the subject I need.More recently, Louise has got her mum involved, branching out into making tactile and fidget cushions which are suitable for dementia patients and people with ADHD, autism and anxiety.Cllr Laura Devlin, chairwoman of Newry, Mourne and Down Council said: ldquoThe Go For It Programme provides new entrepreneurs with accessible, free and tailored support in the start-up stage of her business in areas such as financial and business planning, and sales and marketing to help get their business up and running.ldquoI wish Louise every continued success in developing and growing her enterprise and encourage anyone thinking about starting their own business to get in touch with the Go For It Programme.Joan OrsquoHara, business advisor at Down Business Centre added: ldquoItrsquos great to see Louise doing so well with a product that will undoubtedly support a childrsquos development through sensory play.If you have a business idea yoursquod like to develop oryou are thinking about starting a business contact the Go For It Programme on    or visit: www.goforitni. For further information about Louisersquos business, visit louisessensoryboxes.prettyPhoto

title: Eimear and Gavin nominated for prestigious volunteer accolade
story: TWO local GAA members are in the running for a major volunteering accolade.Eimear Murray, from Loughinisland, and Gavin OrsquoShea, from Ardglass, have been nominated for the Translinkrsquos Young GAA Volunteer of the Year Award.Seven other members of Down clubs have been dominated for the award, which celebrates the outstanding contribution made by young members of the GAA to their clubs and communities throughout the challenges of the Covid- pandemic.Eimear Murray was appointed secretary of Loughinisland GAC last November.In nominating Eimear for the award, the club said: ldquoIt is a huge responsibility and workload in a committee especially at such a young age. However, she has adapted to her new role brilliantly and with complete ease.Gavin helps out with the Ardglass senior squad and is ever present at matches and training sessions.The Ardglass club said: ldquoHe helps with collecting footballs, sorting out training equipment and water bottles, helping to clean the club rooms and grounds. He also keenly gets involved in helping out with any fundraisers.The competition is open to GAA members aged - and the aim is to find those whose actions best demonstrate the volunteering ethos and community spirit of the GAA.The winner will receive a certicate and specially-commissioned Volunteer of the Year merchandise from Ulster GAA. As well as that, courtesy of Translink, there will be a voucher for complimentary Enterprise Class travel for two people to Dublin.The winner also receives a free set of Translink-sponsored underage jerseys for their club..prettyPhoto

title: Families enjoy multicultural event
story: THE County Down Rural Community Network, in partnership with Conradh na Gaeilge, hosted a virtual event to celebrate New Communities Day last Thurday with Syrian families living in Downpatrick.The event attended by Cllr Laura Devlin, chairwoman of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, was a part of wider funding programme.Paula Nixon, community health development officer with the Co Down Rural Community Network, explained: ldquoFamilies have been participating in a series of classes and workshops to gain an introduction and appreciation to the Irish language and culture, including song and dance.ldquoOther events have included a talk about the importance of bilingualism in a multicultural Ireland which aims to empower new communities to sustain their mother tongues both inside and outside of the home.Seaacuten Oacute Murchadha, awareness raising officer with Conradh na Gaeilge, stated: ldquoWe now live in a very erse, multicultural, multilingual society and the Irish language is a valuable cultural asset that we can share with everyone.ldquoEveryone should have the opportunity to derive fun and benefit from it. The Irish language has an important role in helping our new communities integrate into society here and it is for that reason that we are promoting March  as lsquoLaacute na bPobal Nuarsquo or lsquoNew Communities Dayrsquo.Seaacuten said: ldquoConradh na Gaeilge aims to support local communities in developing a positive image of the language for everyone who lives here.ldquoWe are delighted that on a local level we are working with Cumann Gaelach Leath Chathail and the County Down Rural Community Network in promoting todayrsquos event, and we are especially delighted to be working with the Syrian community in Downpatrick. We hope to build on such events going into the future.Dr Hafi Saad, programme facilitator and interpreter, said: ldquoThis has been a good opportunity for Syrian people who are new to Northern Ireland to learn about Irish language and culture.ldquoThe participants have really enjoyed the classes especially during lockdown, it has been a chance to have fun and deepen their understanding of their new home.County Down Rural Community Network would like to thank Conradh na Gaeilge and Department for Communities for funding the programme.They would also like to thank Kevin Magee, the former BBC journalist, who hosted the event and facilitated Irish language sessions, Comhaltas Ceoltoiri Eireann and Sibeaacutel Davitt for facilitating a singing workshop and dancing workshop and providing entertainment on the night, Dr. Francesca La Morgia for her workshop entitled lsquoMother Tonguersquo and Dr Hafi Saad..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 7%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash A Downpatrick man remains in intensive care in a Belfast hospital after being savagely beaten in a vicious weekend assault.The  year-old sustained severe head injuries, including a fractured skull, when he was beaten with what police have described as a metal ball and chain and an ornamental glass kne.The man and three friends were brutally attacked in the Irish Street area during the early hours of last Saturday morning in what has been described as an unprovoked violent attack. A senior police officer has said the motive for the attack may be sectarian.One of the injured men sustained a broken leg during the incident and had to be treated for his injury at the Downe Hospital in the town.At first light on Saturday, a blood-stained part of Irish Street was sealed off by police to allow a detailed search of the area to be carried out. Forensic scientists also combed the area where the assault had taken place in the search for clues.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Dozen more jobs are likely to go from a Ballynahinch firm which laid off  workers last week.Sources within telecommunications company, Viasystems, have this week revealed that  more employees now face the axe. The warning comes just days after all the temporary shop floor workers are released by the company.These employees were told they were no longer needed when they were summoned to a special meeting in the factory on Wednesday.Although management is refusing to comment on claims that more workers are now set to lose their jobs, staff on the permanent pay roll yesterday said they had been warned they may be next to go.Office and shop floor workers were asked to consider voluntary redundancy during an emergency meeting at the factory earlier this week in an effort to achieve the staff cuts.KILLYLEAGH ndash The final fate of Killyleagh High School may have been indirectly sealed by the Education Ministerrsquos recent announcement of the schoolsrsquo budget for .The campaign to reopen the Killyleagh school has been dealt a serious blow following the allocation of a multi-million pound new building grant to Comber High School.The Comber school was awarded poundm within this yearrsquos capital programme, following a -year campaign by the schoolrsquos Board of Governors.The construction of the new Comber school will mark a signicant first for local education because for the first time a private company will build and maintain the new complex. The Department of Education will then pay a ldquomortgagersquo over the next  years.But a source close to the Department has this week warned that the state-of-the-art structure destined for Comber makes it ldquoextremely unlikely Killyleagh High will ever reopen.ARDGLASS ndash A major new education facility in Ardglass opens for business today.The Ardglass Development Association is the driving force behind a new information technology initiative which is based in the villagersquos community centre and funded by the local group.Other key partners include the Rural Development Council, the National Lottery Charities Board and the International Fund for Ireland.The Downpatrick firm of ITA Computers has installed six computers in a specially designed suite and will pave the way for IT training classes to be conducted in the centre.Initial beginners classes, which are being organised in conjunction with the East Down Institute, are free of charge and are scheduled to commence today.DRUMANESS ndash One of the most familiar faces in Drumnaess has bid a fond farewell to the village after  years as the local postmaster.Mr Brian Quinn who, along with we Eileen, took the Mill Road premises over on March , , says deciding to leave his job has been a very hard thing to do.Over the years Brian and Eileen have served the local community, and it hasnrsquot just been selling stamps and sorting letters.As he explained, running Drumaness Post Office was not a normal nine to five job. From early morning Brian would be on the go, delivering groceries, coal and gas, sometimes not finishing until pm or pm at night.Brian says he will hold some very special memories of Drumaness and its residents, and has agreed to continue running the stow until its new owners take over in a few weeks time.CLOUGH ndash The Clough Community Association will soon be able to boast a new computer, thanks to British Telecom.The state-of-the-art facility is due to be installed within the next few days after the local community group impressed BT chiefs behind community connections initiative.The Clough group is one of  across the province to be recognised for its work with local people and the community and its officials are delighted a new computer is on the way.Mr John Knipe, the grouprsquos assistant secretary, said the computer will be used to help produce a local newsletter detailing forthcoming events and activities.NEWCASTLE ndash The Newcastle swimming pool under threat of closure has received a prestigious trophy for its contribution to lesaving.The Rock Pool is to receive the Royal Lesaving Societyrsquos Donaldson Cup, the premier trophy in Northern Ireland for council-owned swimming pools.Campaigners fighting for the retention of the  year-old amenity have said the prominent award highlights the important role the pool plays in the community.To win the award lesaving tutors and students at the pool had to amass more competition points than those at other pools in the Province. The award to the Rock Pool is all the more signicant because it is open for just two months a year and was competing against facilities which are open all year round.CROSSGAR ndash An award-winning Crossgar house, which was once a working mill, is to be featured on television next week.The home of Tom Woolley, Professor of Architecture at Queenrsquos University, and Rachel Bevan, a noted architect, will be featured on UTVrsquos interior design series, lsquoAbout the Housersquo, next Tuesday.The house, which is a conversion of an old ruined water mill, won architectural award from the Royal Society of Architects last year. It is an example of Eco-design in which as much of the existing structure was retained as possible. Most of the new materials were recycled and are free of toxic chemicals.ANNSBOROUGH ndash Irelandrsquos best loved show band legend will make on of his rare County Down appearances this Saturday night at Annsborough GAA social club.Brian Coll has been booked to perform the local gig which is expected to draw big crowds.He will be joined on the night by Banbridgersquos king of yodel, Reggie Gilliland, as well as Donegal singing star Sinead McGavigan.The fabulous lsquoCountry Harmonyrsquo will prove the music for what promises to be a night of top class entertainment.SPORT ndash Sport throughout Down District is facing another weekend wipe-out as a result of the foot and mouth crisis.All rugby, hockey and gaelic games fixtures booked have been cancelled for the second weekend running and soccer looks almost certain to follow suit.The IFA has delayed making a final decision until later today, but the signs are that it will order another shutdown across the province.Last night it was being suggested that a resumption will take place on March  at the earliest..prettyPhoto

title: Jim was pioneering engineer
story: A CROSSGAR man is hoping that a book will be written chronicling the le of a Ballynahinch businessman who featured in a recent novel written by his daughter.The Settlement mdash penned by writer Ruth Kirby-Smith mdash was inspired by her garage owner father Jim Brown whose business was based in Dromore Street.The book is based on a fictional Armagh village, but features a number of local locations including The Spa, the Mournes and a former rectory which is now the Millbrook Lodge Hotel.The novelist is also the sister of John and Junior Brown who are friends with Alan Lyons, well known in local motorsport circles.Alan, who is also one of the driving forces behind the campaign for new memorials in Killyleagh and Crossgar to mark the achievements of former road racer Brian Steenson who lost his le following a crash while competing at the Isle of Man TT in , is looking forward to reading the new novel as it covers a period in Ireland which for him is an ldquointriguing part of history that not much has been written about.Describing James Brown as a ldquoremarkable man, Mr Lyons said it would be fittinga book was written about him and the impact that he had on so many people. While friends with John and Junior, Alan said he was also proud to have known their father very well.ldquoTo say that Jim was an acknowledged engineering genius is no overstatement, he continued.ldquoJim told me that he served his apprenticeship at Stewartrsquos Motor Works in Downpatrick before World War Two and thought the world of James Stewart whom he referred to as lsquogolden handsrsquo because he could turn his hand to anything.ldquoJim then worked for the former Ulster Transport Authority during the war and opened his Antrim Road Garage in Ballynahinch in late  which he purchased with a loan from a family friend.Alan also revealed that Jim and his son John sponsored him when he used to race cars.He continued: ldquoOnce Jim, or JN as he was known, started to help me with mechanical development, I quickly moved from being a back marker to a front runner in no amount of time. Jim always said that % of winning was done in the workshop before the race meetings.ldquoJim was very much a self-made man with an independent pattern of thought and kept his motorcycling hobby quite separate from his business interests, Alan explained.ldquoWhile he preferred not to align himself with any dealership other than David Brown Tractors, for whom he did development work and sold numerous new and second-hand tractors, he steadfastly refused to repair road going motorcycles.Alan revealed that it was Jimrsquos love of motorcycles and an interest in tuning and modying British machines, a process later adopted by manufacturers like BSA, Norton and Triumph in the s that earned him a much-envied reputation.He said James was ldquoalways extremely modest about his dramatic successes as he was happy developing innovation after innovation in his own workshop.ldquoJim was certainly well ahead of his time when explaining in simple terms that engines had to be enabled to breathe easily to make them perform better, Alan explained.ldquoHis new thinking about breathing, valve and camshaft design, carbureation and compression ratios brought phenomenal output at , rpm from an ordinary production BSA machine when the company was the worldrsquos biggest motorcycle producers in the mid-s, long before the surge of Japanese two-strokes.Many years later, Alan said he still finds it hard to understand that Jim Brown was given motorcycles by leading manufacturers with an instruction to keep them winning at world class level, which is exactly what he did.He also revealed that a lot of Jimrsquos ideas were incorporated into the BSA cc Victor machine that Jeff Smith used to win the motocross world championship in  and .Alan revealed that in earlier years, Jim provided Irish champion road-racer Wilfie Herron with a race-bike, as he did for Ian McGregor, Campbell Gorman and Tom Herron.ldquoHailed as a wizard, he personally tailored the BSA bikes which brought Mervyn McConkey so much success on grass tracks and motocross events throughout Ireland, he continued.The Crossgar man said that when Jim lost interest in the motorcycle industry because of its domination by Japanese-built machines, he turned to Cosworth, who employed him as a consultant.ldquoJim became great friends with Keith Duckworth, the English mechanical engineer famous for designing the Cosworth double four valve cylinder engine and cylinder head, and was also great friends with Sir Frank Williams and Sir Patrick Head from the Williams Formula One team, said Alan.ldquoThrough my friendship with Jim and his we Minnie and their sons John and Junior, I met some wonderful people. Jim was great friends with the Rev Harold Good who latter became the Moderator of the Methodist Church in Ireland, while I helped the Brown family run motorsport events in the Martin and McCormickrsquos quarries in the eighties in aid of the Ballynahinch Methodist Church building fund.Mr Brown passed away in  with a huge number of mourners making their way to Ballynahinchrsquos Lough Inch cemetery, including leading names from the world of motorsport including Frank Williams, Patrick Head and Keith Duckworth.ldquoI will always remember Jim as a great innovative, pioneering engineer who was fired by his own initiative. He is someone the like of which we will never see again, said Alan.ldquoIrsquom sure that Ruth will know that her two brothers and I are working on an article on the le and works of her famous father which we have substantially completed and hope to feature in the Down Recorder over the coming weeks, illustrated with a number of photos taken by the paperrsquos former photographer and Ballynahinch man Jim Miskimmin.Alan also confirmed that the Brian Steenson Memorial Group is planning to have a chat show and talk about the le and work of J N Brown later this year when lockdown restrictions have eased. He also revealed that the group will also have a new cup to hand present this year called the J N Brown Memorial Cup donated by his son Junior.The Crossgar man is also appealing to anyone who may have any photos or memorabilia about Jim Brown or Mervyn McConkey to email him at alan-lyons@hotmail and has also wished Ruth every success with her new book which he thinks will be a best seller..prettyPhoto

title: Joe Toner – Ireland%2C  Arsenal and Down star
story: HE was a sporting tour de force who played football for Ireland and Arsenal. Joe Toner also played Gaelic footballer for Castlewellan and lined out on the hurling field for Down.He was born on March , . As a young man, his athleticism earmarked him as a star in the making.The GAA influence was strong one in his family. His nephew Pat Rice was a member of the Down team whichfamously brought the Sam Maguire Cup north of the border for the first time in .Reared at Bunkers Hill, he played soccer for Castlewellan Stars and neighbours Annsborough, before he went on to shine with Belfast United in the midst of World War One.Following the end of the war he came to the attention of Arsenalrsquos talent scouts and was whisked off to the famous London club in , in time for theirto the First Division following promotion.He made his debut against Everton in the newly-built Highbury stadium in October . Wearing the No  shirt, he helped his new team-mates to a - victory. He would go on to make  appearances for the Gunners.Arsenal, like so many post-war clubs, were one in ious stages of flux. The team would change regularly with players often struggling to keep their place for one reason or another.In his second season at the club, he did not feature until December.Arsenal would end the campaign ninth in the table.Despite his infrequent Arsenal appearances, international honours came along. He made his Ireland debut on April , , against Wales. The match at Windsor Park was played in front of a crowd of , and finished in a - draw. He would play eight times in all for Ireland.The arrival of the great Herbert Chapman as manager of Arsenal in  coincided with even fewer chances for Toner.He played only two games at the start of the - season and in January  he went north of the border and signed for Scottish side St Johnstone.However, he was immediately hit by injury, breaking his leg in his first full season. That injury would ultimately force him out of the club at the end of the - season after  games.The following year he ed home to Northern Ireland, going on to coach Coleraine. In fact on one occasion, owing to so many injuries in the Bannsidersrsquo team, he even made a playing appearance.A descendant of Joersquos, Peter Toner, who now lives in Cumbria in England, said Joersquos achievements were a source of great pride to his family.ldquoI had a telephone conversation with his late son Gerard [who passed away in ], who was immensely proud of his fatherrsquos footballing prowess, Peter said.ldquoHe claimed that Joe excelled in any position on the pitch. He recalled him playing for a Whitehaven side, as well as another team in a town a few miles away. That team, we later confirmed, was Cleator Moor.Remarkably, Joe is also remembered with affection at St Johnstone, even though it is almost century since he played for the Perth-based club, which plays at Muirton Park.The official St Johnstone club website still publishes a testament to his role in their history today.ldquoJoe Tonerrsquos place in St Johnstone history is assured by virtue of one simple fact: he was the first player to receive international recognition while playing for the club. He came to Perth from Woolwich Arsenal, having already been capped for his country ndash which was Ireland.ldquoA tricky, pocket-sized left winger, he had an unfortunate start to his Muirton career. He signed in January , and made his debut on the sixth of that month in a First Division match against Motherwell.ldquoSaints lost -, but the Perthshire Advertiser, displaying an unusual degree of inaccuracy noted: lsquoThe Englishman [sic], who is by no means a giant, gave indications of being a sound investment for the Saints. He made the most of any chances he got, but I do feel that he was needlessly starved in the second halfrsquo.In his relatively brief time at Muirton Park he had distinguished himself by becoming the clubrsquos first capped international player.Upon moving back to Castlewellan, his le was touched by tragedy after his we Elizabeth died in her early s from influenza. This left Joe to not only mourn her passing, but to raise their family of ten children single-handedly. He died in Castlewellan in November  at the age of .His descendant, Peter, remarked: ldquoJoe certainly had a remarkable le and left his mark, not just in his local area, but on the playing pitches of England and Scotland too.ldquoThe family are very proud of his achievements, despite the dficulties he experienced at times in his le away from sport..prettyPhoto

title: Katie living the dream on Good Morning Britain
story: SHE dreamed of being a TV weather presenter as a child and now Saintfield woman Katie Andrews has landed her dream job working in television for UTV.The  year-old is a production journalist and has been working on the stationrsquos news bulletins since .She has also become a familiar face in front of the cameras having moved into presenting for Good Morning Britain and weekend news bulletins since last November.Katie said: ldquoI had originally wanted to be a weather woman from a very young age. I always watched breakfast TV news shows before I went to school in the morning and was always attracted to TV news as I always wanted to know what was happening.She took her first step to her ideal career when she applied for the Multi-Media Journalist course at Belfast politan College.ldquoIt was my preferred choice for further education as I admired the coursersquos reputation. It provided me with opportunity to continue my higher education in Multimedia Journalism at Teesside University, where I graduated with a first class honours.Katie said her time at Belfast Met was a springboard for university.ldquoWe did a lot of group projects working in the TV and Radio studios where I had the opportunity to work on the programme Brilliant NI, so I got a real sense of what itrsquos like to self-shoot using industry standard cameras, said Katie. ldquoI also presented some segments of the programme and having this opportunity to present on Brilliant NI was when I realised that I felt comfortable presenting in front of the camera.ldquoMy favourite part of the course was the broadcasting module, as we learnt so much from our lecturers who worked in broadcasting themselves. It helped me to develop the skills I needed to work in TV and broadcasting as a whole. The course was very sociable - everyone worked together well, and we had a lot of fun along the way.After graduating from Belfast Met, Katie continued her higher education journey at Teesside University where she was named Video Journalist of the Year.This award included work experience at a local television channel in the North East of England, North East Live, where she worked as a self-shooting reporter and presenter for for two and a half years before pursuing a career closer to home with UTV.ldquoThere isnrsquot a more exciting and fulfilling job in the world. No two days are the same which I love, and I really get a buzz from working to deadlines every day, she said.ldquoMy work patterns y from producing bulletins, editing, writing and writing articles for our website. The best part of working at UTV is the teamwork thatrsquos involved, and Irsquove also really enjoyed being in front of the camera more recently as well.ldquoI get a real sense of achievement from working behind the scenes with correspondents and reporters that I have always looked up to. Itrsquos so rewarding to see the final news bulletin being broadcast following a busy day in the newsroom.ldquoI feel very lucky to be in the role I am in now, and hope I continue to have a successful career in broadcast journalism and can eventually progress into a reporting role within UTV..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting with minister on school merger plans
story: A DELEGATION of parents and representatives from St Patrickrsquos Grammar School have met with Stormont education minister Peter Weir to discuss the planned merger of three Downpatrick post-primary schools.The online meeting which took place last week was organised by Strangford Assemblyman Harry Harvey, who has described the merger of St Patrickrsquos with De La Salle and St Maryrsquos High Schools as ldquowholly unworkable.The controversial amalgamation has been put forward by the Council for Catholic Maintained Schoolson behalf of the De La Salle Congregation, who are the trustees of all three schools.Public consultation on the plan to open a new co-educational voluntary grammar school for , pupils in Downpatrick in September next year ends on March .Under the merger plan the new school would educate girls and boys aged - with an admission of  pupils per year, with up to a maximum of % of pupils admitted through academic selection. It is intended that existing school campuses would be used ldquopending capital investment for a one site solution.The final decision on the way forward will be taken by Mr Weir who met via Zoom with a delegation of parents and St Patrickrsquos Grammar representatives last Wednesday.The Board of Governors at St Patrickrsquos is opposed to the merger, while both De La Salle and St Maryrsquos are in favour of the plan going ahead.Members of St Patrickrsquos Board of Governors have urged parents, past pupils and the public to respond to the ongoing consultation, asserting that the outcome ldquowill have a lasting impact, not just in the school, with staff and pupils, but its ramications will be felt throughout the local community in East Down.The Board of Governors and school management say they do not believe the case has been made for the proposals as currently outlined and will be re-stating the reasons for this as part of the public consultation process and insist that they are focused on achieving the best outcomes for all concerned.De La Salle High School says the merger will ensure that families in the greater Downpatrick area will have an opportunity to finally get behind the vision to secure the town as a model of good practice, where childrenrsquos education is a priority, while St Maryrsquos High insists that an all-ability school can cater for the gted and talented and also support children who need it.Mr Harvey said he was delighted to be able to secure the meeting with the education minister on behalf of St Patrickrsquos representatives and the ldquomany concerned parents who have contacted him on what he described as ldquothis important issue.He said has been working with them over recent days to ensure that their opposition to the current proposals is made clear to Department of Education officials.ldquoThese efforts culminated in last weekrsquos meeting with the education minister and served as a productive opportunity to enlighten him in respect of many of the key issues on the ground that, I believe, make the current amalgamation plans wholly unworkable, said Mr Harvey.ldquoThe plans, as proposed by CCMS, would reduce academic choice for parents and children from Downpatrick and the surrounding areas.ldquoIt would deny many Catholic schoolchildren the opportunity of attending a local selective Catholic grammar school and the proposed intake criteria would place children living in the rural areas beyond the urban Downpatrick area at a severe disadvantage in terms of the likelihood of being offered a place.Mr Harvey is also urging anyone who has views on the merger of the three Downpatrick schools to take part in the ongoing public consultation which closes on March ..prettyPhoto

title: Naomi named top McDonald’s employee of the year
story: BALLYNAHINCH woman Naomi Hodges has been crowned McDonaldrsquos employee of the yearfor both Northern Ireland and the Republic.She was awarded the top accolade for her role as lsquopeople managerrsquo having played a key role in therecruitment, integration of staff and training  employees at the recently opened McDonaldrsquos at McKinstry Road in Derriaghy.Naomi said it was ldquogreat to be recognised, explaining that the award made her proud of not only herself, but also of the restaurant and team that she works withDescribing the accolade as ldquoa fantastic personal achievement, Naomi also believes it important that her teammates get the recognition as well, as it ldquoshows what a good team we have, especially since we have only been open a matter of months.After studying Marketing and Spanish at the Ulster University in Coleraine, Naomi decided toto education to complete a CIPD Level  in Human Resources Management at Belfast Met ndash something which she says has further enhanced her skill-set.Prior to managing the recruitment process for the new restaurant, she worked in the McDonaldrsquos busy restaurant at Sprucefield, which has over  staff.It was here that she helped develop her organisational and people skills, with one of her achievements being helping to reduce average drive-thru times from  seconds to  seconds in early .Naomi then took on the recruitment and training of the McKinstry Road staff during the pandemic.ldquoThe majority of the process was undertaken virtually, she said. ldquoThere was a lot of communicating and planning with our new team members to ensure everything was as seamless as possible, as well as ensuring face-to-face contact was limited.McDonaldrsquos franchisee John McCollum said the award was a ldquofantastic recognition for Naomi.He said that after what had been a dficult year for many, there was great importance in recognising staff who have consistently displayed the company values and behaviours.ldquoIt goes without saying there have been many outstanding team contributions and I would like to thank the entire McKinstry Road team for their hard work, dedication and commitment so far, he said.ldquoInidual contributions and achievements are equally as important, however, it was obvious that Naomi demonstrates our ethos and values. She epitomises what wersquore all about at McDonaldrsquos how we recognise, look after and train our people. Itrsquos lovely to see her getting recognised in this way.John added: ldquoThere truly are some fantastic employees in the group, but every so often a superstar arrives on the scene and that really is what Naomi is mdash a superstar..prettyPhoto

title: New home for Newcastle FC
story: NEWCASTLE Football Clubrsquos ambitious plans for a new home have been given a huge boost.An application by the club to relocate has been approved by planners and is expected be confirmed by Newry, Mourne, and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee next week.The club hopes to leave its current home at Shimna College and move to Church Hill, off the Castlewellan Road, just outside the town.The exciting development involves the construction of three pitches, including a full-sized intermediate standard grass pitch. There will be two other pitches, one of which will have anarticial G surface.The club is also planning to build a clubhouse along with seating for spectators, fencing and car parking facilities, as well as a new access.Club officials are currently tight-lipped about their plans, which would represent a major boost for soccer in the Newcastle area.The clubrsquos first team has enjoyed considerable success, completing a memorable double in the - season when it won the Cochrane Corry Cup and Division B of the Amateur League.Newcastle won Division A in - and Division IB in  . The club currently plays Division A.The club also has two other teams which compete in the Newcastle League..prettyPhoto

title: New indoor pool plans for Newcastle
story: AN indoor swimming pool and water play area for children are among a number of options being considered as part of the multi-million pound redevelopment of the Newcastle Centre site.While no final decision has yet been taken, the option to provide several -metre swimming lanes and a dedicated play area for children is being examined by council officials.The redevelopment of the Newcastle Centre housed in the historic Annesley Buildings, is one of the key planks of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos capital investment programme and while the preferred option for the new complex is to include some form of water provision, what this will entail has yet to be confirmed.However, the Recorder understands that the provision of several swimming lanes and heated play area for children is under active consideration.Work on a geotechnical survey of the prime town centre site has been completed and once the results of the exercise have been analysed, council officials will decide the next step in the redevelopment project..The survey is understood to have focused on land to the side and rear of the existing Newcastle Centre, including the area around Tropicana which would be demolished as part of any new development.Council officials recognise the need for modern leisure and community facilities in the resortand want to be armed with as much information as possible, including the results of the geotechnical survey, before they proceed.Several options are understood to remain on the table, including an extension to the side and rear of the existing building to provide a modern facility which would crucially include indoor wet weather facilities.While widely regarded as one of Northern Irelandrsquos premier tourist resorts, Newcastle does not have a modern indoor leisure facility which council officials are keen to address in the redevelopment proposal.Two sites were previously identied for a new centre in Newcastle, with sports pitches at Donard Park the preferred option. However, councillors subsequently switched attention to the former St. Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School campus at Shanslieve Drive.Despite a number of protracted attempts to secure the site and hopes that a deal could be agreed, it was bought by supermarket giant Lidl which recently secured outline planning permission to redevelop the site.News that consideration is being given to providing swimming lanes at a redeveloped Newcastle Centre site in tandem with a dedicated water play area for children, comes as the debate around the future of the outdoor Rock Pool at South Promenade in the resort continues.Over , people have signed a petition to preserve the seawater facility which is need of major repair work to address a number of concerning issues following a lack of major investment over many years.Those behind the petition, the Friends of the Rock Pool, want Newry, Mourne and Down Council to carry out the necessary repairs at the facility, with the costs expected to be signicant.Campaigners insist that there is a lot of support for in the community for the restoration and preservation of the outdoor pool, which enjoys protected status.A council spokesman confirmed that the organisation is committed to the Newcastle Centre capital project and has completed geotechnical investigations works at the site, but analysis of the results have not been considered at this stage.He said the preferred option for the new centre includes indoor water provision, but stressed that no final decision has yet been made on the project.ldquoThe Newcastle Centre is included in the capital programme and once results of the geotechnical investigations have been considered, the council will decide the next steps for the project, the spokesman confirmed.In relation to the Rock Pool, he said the local authority has commissioned consultants to complete surveys at the South Promenade site, with the results determining the projectrsquos next steps.The spokesman confirmed that while no decision has been taken to set up a working group to oversee the future for Rock Pool, the local authority has had discussions with a range of stakeholders regarding the facility.He added that at this stage, Newry, Mourne and Down Council has made no decision on future operations of the Rock Pool..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry’s Ciara set to miss out on Euros
story: PORTAFERRYrsquoS Ciara Mageean has withdrawn from the Ireland team to take part in the European Indoor Athletics Championships, which begin tomorrow in Poland.In a shock announcement, Mageean said she was taking the decision after recent ldquosetbacks.The -year old has struggled in her two most recent indoor races in Germany and England.ldquoI am just not where I want to be in order to compete in the European Indoor Champs and do myself and the Irish vest justice, she said.Mageean won the bronze medal in the m at the last European Championships in Glasgow two years ago.She said she had decided to opt out of the championships following consultations with her Manchester-based coach Steve Vernon.She said she felt the decision was the right one in order to best prepare for the summer ahead. Ciara became the first Irishwoman to go under two minutes for m last summer when she improved the national record to .. in a milestone performance.She then broke Sonia OrsquoSullivanrsquos -year-old Irish m record during arguably the best performance of her career in a stellar field in Monaco. However afterwards, her form dipped in the closing three outings of her outdoor campaign.She appeared to be back on the right path back when she comfortably broke nine minutes to win a m in Manchester in early January.However, she finished a distant last in her m race at the World Indoor Tour meeting in Karlsruhe, Germany.Afterwards she said the unexpected death of her former coach, Jerry Kiernan, the previous week, had taken ldquomore from me than I anticipated.She attempted to regroup in a relatively low-key m race in Manchester a couple of weeks ago, but could only finish fourth in a time of ....prettyPhoto

title: RAPID bin made more visable
story: A BIN designed to help people safely get rid of preion and illegal drugs has been relocated in Downpatrick.Formerly located the rear of the SuperValu store at the Ballymote Centre on the outskirts of the town, the bin has been moved closed to the front of the building.The so-called remove all prescription and illegal drugsbin has been relocated by the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership which is planning to provide a number of others.RAPID is an initiative launched in partnership with the PSNI and Action on Substances through Education and Related Trainingthat promotes and facilitates the removal of all types of prescription and illegal drugs from the local community.The overall aim of the RAPID initiative is to reduce risk at inidual, family and community levels in relation to drug use and availability.Community Safety Partnership chairman, Cllr John Trainor, hopes that relocating the RAPID bin to a more visible location will encourage people in the community to use it and dispose of illegal drugs and unused prescription medication in a safe and anonymous way.ldquoAbuse of illegal and prescription drugs ruins lives and any measure that can be introduced to help is welcome, he continued. ldquoThe success of the RAPID bins in other areas of the council are a testament to the effectiveness of this approach.Pamela Quiery, of the South Eastern Drug and Alcohol Co-ordination Team, said it was delighted to be involved in the RAPID partnership and working with the local policing and community safety partnership and supporting the initiative.ldquoWe have no doubt that the relocation of the RAPID bin in Ballymote to a more accessible site will bring greater usage.The key aim behind the RAPID bins is to tackle the growing issue of drugs in communities and to allow iniduals to safely dispose of illegal drugs and unused prescription medication in a safe and anonymous way.The initiative is partnership approach between ASCERT, Public Health Agency, PSNI, and the PCSP, the latter which is in the process of identying new locations to install further RAPID bins across the district to help combat the illegal use of drugs and prescription medication within local communities.Further information on existing RAPID bins is available by emailing the PCSP at pcsp@nmandd.org..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick musical set for debut
story: A MUSICAL based on the story of St Patrick will be performed for the first time on St Patrickrsquos Day.The St Patrickrsquos Show is being broadcast from the St Patrick Centre on March .And the stars of the show will be two of Downpatrickrsquos best known performers mdash soprano Mary McCabe and musician and singer Matthew Campbell, who is a member of the acclaimed Shamrock Tenors.The -minute show is described as a ldquojourney through the ages inspired by stories and legends from Saint Patrickrsquos time right up to modern day Irish poetry.It also features features  Grammy nominated Fontaines DC frontman Grian Chatten, and other Irish artists. It is directed by Belinda Murphy, of Riverdance, Vikings and Disneyrsquos Disenchanted fame.This launch event is a precursor to a series of live events that will be held in Downpatrick thissummer, Covid restrictions permitting.These will include a live version of the Saint Patrick Show, which will incorporate a three- course dinner menu from Saint Patrickrsquos Plate, a cookery book written by award winning Irish chef Terry McCoy.The Saint Patrick Show has been funded with assistance from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, the Community Foundation for Northern Ireland, Newry Mourne  Down Council and Fingal County Council.You can see a promotional video of the show by going to https:youtu.be iicaZh-b..prettyPhoto

title: Steven’s farm calendar raises thousands for Air Ambulance
story: AN amateur photographer from Co Down has raised a staggering pound, for the Air Ambulance Northern Ireland.Steven Evans, from Kirkistown, sold , copies of his agriculture calendar featuring imagery of farming contractors working on the Ards Peninsula.Stevensays photography and fresh air helped him through the long days after he was furloughed from his job as an automatic greaser technician during the early part of last yearrsquos pandemic lockdown.ldquoThis whole thing started out as nothing more than a comment-in-passing by one of the contractors, who spoke to me when I was out photographing their machinery working in the fields, he explained.ldquoThe thought of creating a calendar stuck in my head and, well, here we are today handing over a lot of money.ldquoThe initial idea of creating  calendars soon got out of hand and before long , copies had been printed.ldquoThe contractors featured within the calendar covered the printing costs and with all copies sold, as well as donations, handing over pound, to such a great charity is incredible.ldquoNone of this would ever have been possible without the generosity of the contractors, as well as those who bought the calendars from many local businesses who agreed to sell them on my behalf.ldquoOnly today, when doing the cheque handover, have I realised what has been achieved.Steven added: ldquoThe support has been overwhelming from the rural community, mainly on the Ards Peninsula where the calendar was photographed, showing just how much of a benefit they feel the Air Ambulance NI is.Grace Williams, Area Fundraising Manager for Air Ambulance NI, said: ldquoWe are so inspired by the creativity and generosity we are seeing from the public across Northern Ireland and the agricultural sector.ldquoSteven Evansrsquo story of creating this calendar after he had been furloughed from work is a real inspiration and we are humbled that he wanted to do this in support of Air Ambulance NI.ldquoAs a service we rely heavily on charitable donations to keep the medical team in the air, delivering critical care to patients who have suffered trauma throughout Northern Ireland mdash without this type of support, the team simply couldnrsquot fly.ldquoThe past year has been especially challenging for fundraising and wersquove seen a dramatic downturn in our income. Every single penny counts.Grace added: ldquoWe want to say a huge thank you to Steven and everyone who has supported sales of his amazing calendar..prettyPhoto

title: Towns could benefit from task force plan
story: TOWNS and villages across the district could benefit from a new Stormont initiative designed to support the local economy.The Northern Ireland Executiversquos High Street Task Force has been set up to help breathe new le into high streets in particular which have undergone major change over recent years.And given the impact of Covid- on the business community, the Executive is keen to help with its recovery.The new task force says the way people work, live, shop, enjoy leisure, access services and travel is dferent today compared to  or  years ago.The task force says while the pandemic has accelerated and deepened this change, its roots pre-date this with retail trends, the prevailing economic mood and broader business landscape creating an uncertain back.Those behind the task force which includes key government departments, business organisations universities, the voluntary and community, arts and tourism sectors, aim to identy the challenges and solutions and actions that can be taken to support High Streets and city centres.The creation of the new task force has received a guarded welcome from Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran who is backing the vision to help town centres and villages become thriving places for people to do business, socialise, shop, be creative and use public services as well as being great places to live.ldquoThis is a very welcome initiative and while it is early days, I hope that the task force will achieve its goals at a time when the business community is facing its greatest ever challenge, he continued.ldquoIt is a vision that will require everyone working together and the broadest possible buy-in from those who live and work in towns and villages.Cllr Curran said while what has been mapped out for towns and villages represents a long term project, the Executive says that it is committed to address the many challenges faced by those in business.He also agrees that high streets are more than just places to shop, they are a focal point for the community, in particular, those in Downpatrick, Newcastle and Ballynahinch.ldquoThe task force is determined to build something new and will not be resisting change or trying to reinvest the past. I believe that post-Covid we can work to improve the night-time economy of our main towns and villages which will boost the local economy and potentially help attract new investment, suggested Cllr Curran.ldquoIn the Newry, Mourne and Down area there is now an opportunity to create thriving high streets and villages and while there is a tough challenge ahead, nothing will be achievedall of us not seize the initiative and look to the future with confidence.Cllr Curran said he is particularly pleased that the task force is insisting that working alongside local government in moving forward will be one of its priorities.He added: ldquoRevitalising our town centres could also pave the way for people to live there again, with businesses releasing space above their premises for new accommodation..prettyPhoto

title: When Frankie Fitzsimons claimed his final winner
story: THE East Down point-to-point meeting of , which took place on March  at David Corbettrsquos estate at Tyrella, brought the curtain down for Frankie Fitzsimons.The popular Downpatrick jockey decided to call time on his long and successful career in the saddle after winning the opening race, the Alan Dunlop confined hunt race on his own horse, Killinick Robyn.Frankie always said to me that when he made the decision to retire, I would be the first reporter to know. True to his word, he informed me right away, sayingPeter Scudamore could do it, so could he.The race saw  of the  entries go to post, with Frankie making the early running. With three fences to go, the leader was Dave Anthony, ridden by John Bright, with Brian Hamilton chasing on John Turleyrsquos Friendless Friend.Anthony then crashed out and Hamilton was unseated from Fearless Friend, leaving Frankie on Killinick Robyn to win from Darragh Cross owner Judith OrsquoGradyrsquos Another Partner, ridden by James Lamb, with Raymond Martinrsquos Kasperova and Paul Parkin third.The best horses that Frankie rode over the years were Jim Gloverrsquos Hopersquos Choice, trained by his father and namesake, Frankie Sr.Frankie Sr also owned and trained young Frankiersquos first winner under rules, Bright Trick, in a Hunterrsquos Chase at Downpatrick in .One of his most notable winners was Joe Rearsquos Palo. Trained by Peter McCreery, it was the result of a big gamble the day that Frankie rode it to success at Navan.His reward that day from Joe, renowned as Downpatrickrsquos ldquobusy draper, was a new suit. I believe he still wears it on special occasions.The following week at Johnnie Grantrsquos Ramble Inn at Ballykilbeg, Frankie threw a big party for all his friends in the sport. I was lucky enough to be invited and it was a great night. Former amateur and top local funny man Terence McKeag was acting as MC. Frankie took to the stage to play the guitar and sing.Thankfully, Frankie has not been lost to the sport as he is now an officer at point-to-points, as well as being the inspector of courses. He is also a qualied steward at meetings north and south.Also at Tyrella in  there was a local winner in the two-winner race with Moving Statue, trained at Banbridge by Leo Young and ridden by Alfie Evans winning for Dromara owner David Hanna.The six-year old geldings race saw Ian Buchanan ride his own Some Day Soon to success and the Douglas and Cromie Maiden race was won by Mrs Stuart Catherwoodrsquos Bad Boy, ridden by Paddy Graffin.In the open race, Pyral, owned and trained by Moirarsquos Therese OrsquoNeill, and ridden by Graeme Martin proved to be too good for the hot favourite Mill Park Bay, ridden by Pat Kelly.At the Warwick meeting on Friday, Downpatrick jockey Caoilin Quinn recorded his first success for an outside stable when he won the racingtv Conditional Jockeys Handicap Hurdle on the   favourite Eaton Miller, trained by R Potter.Despite the fact that the race was for conditional jockeys, Caoilin was again listed on the card as a Mr. He had been a professional at this stage since early-January.This is something that does not make sense as, at present, amateur riders are unable to compete and sadly will not be able to do so at the Cheltenham Festival.They have always been a big feature of the action there, with so many Irish riders involved. Top riders like Patrick Mullins, Derek OrsquoConnor, Noel McParlan, Jamie Codd, and Barry OrsquoNeil are as effective as any professional.They are working with horses every day of the week, so it is a big disappointment for them and many others.Congratulations to Cumbria- based Downpatrick jockey Danny McMenamin on riding his th career winner. He led   shot Archie Brown at the recent Market Rasen meeting.At present, Danny leads the conditional jockeys title race on  winners. He is five ahead of Cork-born Bryan Carver. He started off in pony racing and is based with Nicky Richards, as was Anthony Dobbin..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. Traffic levels are a fraction of those crossing the English Channel, which links London and Paris, both of which alone have a population larger than Northern Ireland and Scotland combined.On a radio discussion some years ago I applauded the ambition of a tunnel to Scotland but said it would not happen for + years. That timescale was met with surprise But I have seen how long it has taken to deliver far simpler schemes. I first started taking an interest in the inadequate road links between Belfast and both Dublin and Londonderry in the s. More than  years later, both roads are still not full expressways . The road from Cairnryan Stranraer to the English border, the A, is even worse and is single carriageway for almost all of its  miles.Some politicians also call Boris Johnson’s bridge tunnel ‘fantasy’. It isn’t. It might well be an attempt to distract political attention from his Irish Sea border, but it is plausible. It just is not remotely a current priority, given modest traffic levels and immense costs.I think of it as a nd century goal — a project to be delivered by  perhaps  If it is, then plenty of the younger children of today will live to see it.• Ben Lowryis News Letter deputy editor• Ben Lowry: Whatever future the PM adopts for NI seems set to lead to crisis• Ben Lowry in : The Boris bridge to Scotland plan is a nice dream but a distant one• Letter: A Scotland-NI tunnel would be boost to Belfast and to rail travel——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
